content:
1, 2015
												Marvel Heroes is an absolute blast to play! So many diverse characters to choose from (with a new one added each month!) and several different game modes to play as well. Best of all you can get all the characters for free using in game currency which is easy to collect! Players don't have to worry about being "left behind" either as there's a variety of content for players of every skill and character level with more to come.The game has come a long, long way since beta thanks to weekly content additions and updates from one of the hardest-working and most community interactive dev teams I've ever seen. Heck, even Gazillion's CEO streams regular play sessions of the game and gets involved with the community! The devs have a passion for Marvel and for games, shown by an amazing level of attention to detail and quality control.Speaking of which, the community in this game is one of the best bar none. So many helpful and friendly folks it's a welcome change of pace!I highly recommend the game to not just Marvel or ARPG fans, but to anyone that wants a fun and engaging MMO to play!And did I mention it's free? ;)

content:
y 22
												I once loved this game.  I got hooked back in beta, and was entralled from the beginning.  It was the closest thing any of us had to an updated version of Diablo 2, and Brevik even brought his famed hidden cow levels with him.  As of this review, I have 767 hours in the game, and probably about $150 in it.  My friends and I have enjoyed it for hours on end, and I even had an entire inventory tab purchased to hold items for giving to friends who tried the game for the first time, to twink their characters a bit.Now?  I could never recommend this game to someone unless I hated that person.  Gazillion removed everything that made the game special, including Brevik, and instead have adopted all of the worst traits of a forgettable Diablo 3 clone, (which itself is a very mediocre game with a much better company behind it).  It has always been Marvel's MO to screw writers out of their rights to make a quick dollar (Google "marvel comics screws writers"), so maybe that's what happened here, and Gazillion rolled over because they just didn't know better before making a deal with the devil.  Or maybe Gaz is taking Marvel's name through the dirt in some elaborate revenge plot by Jack Kirby, I don't know.If you hate yourself, and want to see slow, pathetic parodies of your favorite Marvel heroes characters, then sure, get a spoon and start digging into this pile of ♥♥♥♥.  If you don't desperately need mental health services, and if you're looking for a proper game similar to Diablo 2, Path of Exile is worth a look.

number of helpful: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
2
												When I first played this game, I was like, "Sweet! It's a Diablo-style Marvel game! Awesomeness!" Being a fan of both, I started devoting several hours to the game almost every day (and have since sunk over 500 hours into it). Then they started making changes...The first big changes I noticed were the removal of difficulty settings (which I'm glad they've now changed back) and that costumes stopped dropping. The difficulty was permanently set to "stupidly easy" everywhere except level 60-only areas, so I needed to mindlessly grind to level 60 before anything was even remotely challenging. I say mindlessly because I'd have to actively try to die to even fall below 75% health. I could literally sit still and have my team-up do all the work. Then, I'd open up the level 60 areas, some of which had the difficulty sharply increase to "frustratingly difficult not to die every 5 seconds".I'm not sure if costumes were always an ultra rare drop, but before that update, I had two or three just from drops, and never did once after that. I read somewhere it was something ridiculous like a 0.2% chance from cosmic bosses if you max out special item find, or whatever. At any rate, I get that it's incentive to fork over cash to just straight-up buy them, which is fine. However, I've read that they've since reinforced their "Give us money!" incentive by making costumes even harder to get in-game, which, is that really necessary? I feel like more than enough people were paying players, so that's just ridiculous. Maybe I'm wrong?Then, there was "the big update". Lots of hate went around. I liked the return of difficulties and grew to somewhat like the simplicity of the new power trees and infinity system, so I kept playing. My big problem with the game, and what makes me "screw this game, I quit" level of angry after putting over 500 hours of my life into it is that they're even more strongly sticking it to casual free-to-play players (like me) by making things you used to be able to acquire with in-game currency entirely impossible to get without paying real-life money. I saved eternity splinters specifically to acquire a certain handful of team-ups (I wasn't in a hurry, since I had other ones to level up in the meantime, so I was saving to buy them all at once). I logged in today to find that I cannot. They're just not available anymore, apparently. I'm so angry about this, so, screw this game, I quit.

Then they started making changes...The first big changes I noticed were the removal of difficulty settings (which I'm glad they've now changed back) and that costumes stopped dropping. The difficulty was permanently set to "stupidly easy" everywhere except level 60-only areas, so I needed to mindlessly grind to level 60 before anything was even remotely challenging. I say mindlessly because I'd have to actively try to die to even fall below 75% health. I could literally sit still and have my team-up do all the work. Then, I'd open up the level 60 areas, some of which had the difficulty sharply increase to "frustratingly difficult not to die every 5 seconds".I'm not sure if costumes were always an ultra rare drop, but before that update, I had two or three just from drops, and never did once after that. I read somewhere it was something ridiculous like a 0.2% chance from cosmic bosses if you max out special item find, or whatever. At any rate, I get that it's incentive to fork over cash to just straight-up buy them, which is fine. However, I've read that they've since reinforced their "Give us money!" incentive by making costumes even harder to get in-game, which, is that really necessary? I feel like more than enough people were paying players, so that's just ridiculous. Maybe I'm wrong?Then, there was "the big update". Lots of hate went around. I liked the return of difficulties and grew to somewhat like the simplicity of the new power trees and infinity system, so I kept playing. My big problem with the game, and what makes me "screw this game, I quit" level of angry after putting over 500 hours of my life into it is that they're even more strongly sticking it to casual free-to-play players (like me) by making things you used to be able to acquire with in-game currency entirely impossible to get without paying real-life money. I saved eternity splinters specifically to acquire a certain handful of team-ups (I wasn't in a hurry, since I had other ones to level up in the meantime, so I was saving to buy them all at once). I logged in today to find that I cannot. They're just not available anymore, apparently. I'm so angry about this, so, screw this game, I quit.

												I was actually really excited about the Biggest Update Ever, after my friend told me about it. Mind you, I didn't even know about it, so I did not know about the testing they did or feedback user's have given. But when I tried it out the first time, I was honestly disappointed. It feels like they took a step backwards instead of forward, again, that is what I feel and is my opinion. I did not spend as many hours as quite a few people, but I played quite a lot of the game and enjoyed it most of the time. I gave this update a few tries, but after feeling really bored trying out all of my heroes, I have not had a second thought about launching the game. I will wait until the Omega items are released, which I do not know why it was not released with such a big update already, but anyhow, I am not someone who knows what decisions some companies make. It isn't even just the movement change that really bothered me, that is something I could get used to, but it just isn't fun anymore. I don't have any 'goal' to reach for any of my heroes I play. I tried re-gearing some of my heroes, but after doing so many times and trying out different variations, I just had to stop and really think "What do I do after this?"Again, I am not someone who put hundreds of hours into the game, but I played a decent amount and was not done with end game content before this update and was anticipating it once I found out about it. My review may change depending on what content is released in the near future hopefully, but for now, it will remain on the negative side. If there are new players, do not take the review as "This game sucks", please do try it if you have any interest in it, as it may be fun for you.

content:
y 9
												I played a decent amount of hours in this game, because for the first hours it's rather funny, and then you continue just hoping to discover more in depth dynamics and content. But just no, in the end you realize that this game has really no depth at all.You level up to 60 your toon and then it's just grinding, and grinding, and grinding again and... did I mention grinding?The missions are really all dumb and repetitive after the end of the campaign (the campaign is not great but at least it's ok). Then you are hit by the lack of fantasy, lack of challenge, lack of meaningful skills, lack of articulated and immersive stories. The only challenge of the missions is the material difficulty to beat enemies that are above your level. But you only have to grind more for that. The most difficult thing about missions is to understand how the mission tracker works (and you end up discovering that often it simply doesn't work as it should).BTW, also the social part is very poorly implemented. And be careful to what you say in the game chat. Mods are really trigger happy in banning people without advice.PRO:- Marvel superheroes fans could like this, because the graphics are nice, although poorly optimized (but even a lot of hardcore fans will get bored soon by the lack of content).CONS:- Plagued by servers lag and bugs.- Heroes are not well balanced, some are OPs, some are just bad.- Missions are really repetitive and boring.- When you hit the level 60 cap, the game fun basically ends, because it all gets confusing and repetitive, and you have no more a clear feeling of the character's progression.- The social part is severely lacking. The chat is very basic and confusing. Chat moderators are trigger happy with bans.VOTE: 5/10 (could be a 6/10 or a bit more if they would release more endgame content and italian language)                                   -----------------------------------VOTE UPDATE: 4/10 after the january 2017 patchThey eliminated the only thing that made the game still interesting after leveling up your toon to 60, the Omega system. The infinity system is just a streamlined way of making you grind a lot more hours (or to make you pay to win) to acquire few points, and then not allowing you to chose where to spend your hard earned infinity points.Also, all the toons movement powers have been nerfed down to the level of unplayability, and all the powers unlock  automatically based on your level, so goodbye to custom characters builds.

content:
10, 2014
												I've played for a year so I can give you my honest opinion:This game could be better. It's Diablo MMO style but in marvel universe. People complain about the fact you can't create your own character and you have to use the standard marvel heroes and you will find thousands of ironmans flying arround. But actually this is not the main problem in this game.I really don't mind to be forced play with the marvel characters and have to look same heroes everywhere. The REAL FACT of why I don't recomend this game is: Pay to Achieve/Unlock, but definitely not P2W.You will start with one of "starter" heroes that, with the exception of Captain America and Punisher, aren't so popular between the fans. The most popular heroes are the most expensive and not available for starter heroes choice.The only way to unlock those heroes for free is collecting Eternity Splinters, kind of special coin droped in map when you defeat enemies. The drop rate is 10 per hour and this is a big problem, because:Most popular and cool heroes cost for free: 600 eternity splintersMedium popular heroes: 400 eternity splintersComum heroes: 200 eternity splintersIf you want to unlock Ironman for example, you will have to play for long 20 hours doing the same thing: walking arround, killing mobs and collecting stuff....IS THIS GAME PAY TO WIN?No. All heroes have a great potencial in diferent roles. All will depend of your playstyle, equipment and skill. You can buy the expensive Thor with real money or eternity splinters, but you still can be defeated by a cheap Black Widow.IS THIS GAME PAY TO FUN?YES. unless you like to play with the same heroe the entire campaign and expend weeks farming eternity splinters. I UNDERSTAND the company has to pay his taxes and this money have to come from somewhere. BUT EVERYTHING IN THIS GAME IS MADE TO MAKE YOU BUY SOMETHING, YOU DON'T ACHIEVE NOTHING BY PLAYING THE GAME ITSELF. THERE IS NO CHALLENGE, NO OBJECTIVE, NOWHERE TO GO... JUST COMPLETE THE CAMPAIGN AND BUY OUR STUFF IN STORE BECAUSE YOU KNOW, IT'S MARVEL UNIVERSE, WE DON'T HAVE TO MAKE YOU ENJOY THE GAME.In other words: Spend your money or get bored.They already have the heroes and costumes market, the boosts and special services like portable crafter and power point reset. Is Eternity Splinters really necessary? The company will fall if the players could unlock the heroes spending in-game credits? The answer is no.This game still standing only because it's Marvel. The good free to play games must follow some standards:FIRST play the game and enjoy;SECOND spend some money because you really liked the game.I'll take Neverwinter as an example of a good F2P game. The game is free, but is so creative and funny that make you spend money just for love by the game and the company.Marvel heroes just make the oposite: you will hate the game first and after spending some money, you will love it, a perfect example of a bad free to play game that should be a paid game: FIRST PAY AND SECOND HAVE FUN.

content:
r 30, 2016
												Marvel Heroes 2016.  This is a Free to Play Action RPG.  If you like Action RPGs and Marvel Comic books, then give it a try.  Players starts with 1 Marvel media character.  Everyone plays a Marvel character.  From Marvel Comics and Media universe, has a mix of 60 playable superheroes and supervillains  while fighting other classic supervillians and meeting other characters as NPCs, questgivers.  Has other heroes as fighting companions that you can add.  Devs have given out free certain characters for Marvel characters movie and tv releases. (Currently, i have 23 heroes, 7 companions, 3 bank boxes and 7 pets for FREE after 662 days of logins, have not paid any money).PROS:- Level cap is level 60.- Combat and questing is easy, and new gear falls regularly. - Game has events that increase the amount of loot dropping and buffs that do the same. - Has good graphics, voiceovers and sounds. -  Has a daily login reward system, which also gives character unlocks and shards.- You can try out all characters to level 10, but that is not long.- Certain loot ( Eternity Shards ) in game can be collected to eventually unlock another character (costs 200, 400, 600) and those shards drops regularly (1 per hour played). CONS:- There is only one story, so once you finish it with one character, you have seen the story.  - Replay value is only in grinding each hero you unlocked to level 60 and the end game grind for gear, to play harder Co-Op end game missions.  -You will run out of room in your bank, might be forced to pay money for bank space, unless you wait for bank box giveaway events. - There is no reason to team up, till you reach end cap. - Devs completely changed the gameplay after the last major Update (jan 2017), according to the recent negative reviews. Devs are changing this PC game to be a console game. 1. Quickbars have been reduced from a rotating 8 slot quickbar with 3 other sets to a Single 8 slot quickbar.  All characters have way more than 8 powers that a player will want to use.2.  Devs Nerfing or Destroying certain popular hero builds.3.  Devs making the gameplay Slower than it was before the Update.Try it, maybe you might like it.  New players might not see any problems with the game.For more info:

content:
9
												So I don't know where to start.  I guess I will start with I have 1300 hours between 2 different accounts.  The first time I just got really burnt out, got rid of the account and made a new one and have played that for hundreds of hours, probably about 5-600 on the new account just until a few weeks ago, I'd say 2 weeks past the "big update" was the last time I played the game.  The Issues I have with this game is a lot of the same that you read from every other review, I don't do reviews but with the announcement that came with marvel Heroes Omega I figured it was time to voice my displeasure, and doing so on the forums tends to be removed or knowed down by the fan boys.The game lacks serious content, there are 3 one shot's, 2 differnet raids (green and red difficulty for one, the other only green (been probably 2-3 years since red was promised) 3 patrols where 90% of where you spend the game just killing trash mobs and the occassional bosses, a decent chunk of terminals, which last between 3-5 minuets, and then 10 chapters of a story where the company basically expects you to spend your time because that is what they want to focus on.  End game is just grinding mobs for gear, that is it, just gear collecting you can prestiege to different colors to restart your level grind, but no paragon mode, no extra difficulties, although we were told that will come eventually.The Pc version of the game is still missing a serious amount of content to satisfy and not burn out a player, yet they announced the ps4 version which is coming with half the heroes, half the content, so we will have to sit back while they play catch up.  So for the forseeable future there is no new content on the horizon, no new heroes (the past 2 heroes: Black Bolt and Nick Fury were rushed, and fury is plain awful.)Lastly this was a response in a pm I got from one of the staff regarding One-Shots "We love them too, but due to their size and the time it takes to make new environments, it is really hard to justify the time spent on them." I wonder what other aspects such as raids they feel the same way about and we will not get.

content:
3, 2016
												As I write this review I cannot recommend this game right now. New content takes forever to come out and when it does, like chapter 10 for example it can be cleared in less than 20 minutes. Their tournaments for the danger room are poorly executed where as only a select amount heroes can achieve top time instead of  any hero properly geared. Heroes are highly unbalanced where some like Luke Cage who has been in the game since launch is so bad, or rogue who is over powered and doesn't get tuned properly.  Most content is just about how fast can you kill things. Despite the whole defense system rework nothing changed people don't gear more defensively and heroes like Nightcrawler are still squishy as hell.  Now they are reworking the blessing system, cause everyone uses the same blessing (Hela Blessing) From the math people have done a lot of people will still use the same one after the rework which now accomplishes nothing. They redesigned the prologue for the 3rd time now which really didn't need that instead of fixing what is in dire need of being fixed. With the omega system 90% of the nodes are not used because they are useless. Everyone picks  % damage or fighting burt or crit damage and hit, and stats like speed are useless.  New characters like Ultron are just copy and paste of other heroes mashed together. The trade community doesn't know how value of items work as it constantly fluctuates  week to week 1 minute a gok(gem of the kursed) is worth 2-4 blessing then a event happens and they go up to 15+ instead of going down due to  more currency being available. The Devs as a team have really went down hill since David Brevik and Doomsaw have left. Anytime asked about something you get the vague answer of we cant promise anything or we will look into it. Coming soon a lot of the time never comes.  Gifting people some times leads to a ban(my friend gifted a friend of his and got banned for they suspected he was working with 3rd party vendors.) Over all its not a terrible game and it has a very large cast of heroes even if more then half are either poorly done or just been ignored since release. The game from2014 to 2015  was head and shoulders in changes, but  2015 to 2016 has 0 improvement. This is IN MY OPINION of why I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

They have gutted this game.My playtime is not reflected on steam, I have well over 3000 hours in this game since it came out. I update it outside of steam however due to issues with the steam update.This game is undergoing a half ♥♥♥♥♥ port for console and as a result they are basically copy and pasting systems from D3 into the game (i'm not sure how there isn't a lawsuit in the works really, paragon system the torment level slider etc). They have removed everything that contained the flavor of the original game including the movement. Imposing ramp up times on movement powers, timers, restricting teleport ranges and adding counters to limit how often you can use them. Now instead of feeling like a super hero you feel like an invalid. The basis for endgame progression, uniques and omega points are now gone converted at pennies for dollars to a paragon system like d3 where the points you had control over are now divied up between 5 nodes. I had 10k omega points and could feel the effect of every one I allovated. The new system gives me 170 in each node and I honestly can't tell the difference if I forget to alloccate them or not. The original Devs are gone and along with them all the good will from their playerbase, visit their forums and reddit and you will see an overwelming groundsurge of protest against what they are doing. Not only don't they care, they have been banning people for dissention and closing threads left and right censoring any and all posts that fly in the face of their new world order. Not only will I never play this piece of garbage again but if Gaz ever developes another game I will avoid it like it's poison.

content:
y 21
												Although I cannot recommend this game to people at the moment, the changes made in the last few days are not what is killing the game for me. I feel that many of the recent negative reviews are targeting the wrong aspects of the game. While the concerns are somwhat justified, many criticisms are half-truths. So many people are not explaining why these specific changes are an issue for the game as it has been for the last year. I played this game during beta and early release, left, and then came back to it in 2015.  While the movement changes certainly have negatively affected the speed of most heroes, it makes sense that heroes such a Hawkeye, Cap, Taskmaster, Iron Man, etc aren't just zipping around the map with their dashes. Did it honestly make sense that Iron Man or Warmachine would just dash around a map instead of flying? It does suck not being able to move across the map as quickly with some people, but one of the reasons that map movement was so crucial is because few mobs in this game are actually worth killing. Minions and other small mobs simply do not offer the player anything. It is not worth killing anything that isn't a boss because they will simply drop nothing for a player. I have never seen this in any other arpg and it has been this way since I came back to this game in 2015. After leveling, bosses are pretty much the only things that will drop significant enough xp or items. You needed the movement to get to the boss as soon as possible and then kill the boss for your very small chance at loot. Sure, smaller mobs in other arpgs usually don't drop anything, but in Marvel Heroes, the only thing worth killing is a boss unless the game forces you to kill them in order to progess. A change to the way non-boss mobs contribute or provide xp or loot would make it feel worthwhile to stick around and actually kill them, thus reducing the need to constantly be moving to the next objective as quickly as possible. Another change that people have criticized is the damage done to build and item diversity. While I feel that concerns are valid, my opinion on these matters is probably different a great deal of the community. Let's take hero builds and the removal of ability points for example. Ability points were an interesting mechanic, and are something that is not present in many current arpgs these days. It is sad to see it go, but they didn't povide as much build diversity as you might think. For the past year and a half, most heroes have had somewhat predetermined builds.  When I came back to ths game, Punisher had just recently been reworked and the game was already showing signs that build choice would come down to talents. Punisher was given two diverging passive traits that augmented different powers. You could not pick both, you had to pick one or the other and maxed your powers based on these choices. I don't know if this trend was started earlier, but I feel that power choice has been somewhat limited for a long time. If you were min-maxing, chances are that the hero you were playing had a few trait determined builds, and you maxed the most efficient powers for that build. Most of the time, it was not hard to figure out what was worth maxing and putting on your bar. A lot of the slots were pretty set in stone as well. You maxed your sig, your offensive passve, and possibly your defensive passive(41-61 points). You left travel powers and dashes at one point, and then you went from there. The biggest change with the talent system is that it only allows you to use up to 1 bar. While this doesn't hurt most people, it does a select few who could utilize more than one bar. Heroes such as Rogue, Dr. Strange, and Iron Fist were able to utilize more than one bar, and this made for some very interesting game play. Now, those builds are gone, and it does hurt their gameplay for some people. In addition to this, it still feels like hero balance is way off. I have not had enough time to test most of the heroes, but I have seen drastic performance rates in those that I have played in the new cosmic content areas. If you don't have someone who can either tank up the damage, or dodge abilities, cosmic areas have too much hp and just one shot you. I've found a few exceptions, but some of the heroes that I've geared significantly can't do it easily. As far as gearing goes, let's not kid ourselves, guys. Gearing in the last year or so has pretty much been: Fragment, skrull hammer, crossbones rifle, hero unique slot 1; x-men, darkhawk, sinister, or hero unique slot 2; coat of skull, monarch cloak, hero unique slot 3; batroc's, skrull uniform, or hero unique slot 4; mask of goat, djinn, octobot controller, or possibly hero unqiue slot 5. Unique item choice was not really unique. There was a ton of gear that used to be okay, but was rendered garbage by newer hero uniques. Many any hero uniques were just straight up vendor trash. They served no purpose other than being traded in for credits or runes. Invuln cores were absolutely necessary. Artifact choice had some diversity, but you had specific sets for phys, energy, multi damage, or summoner. There was also the issue where fighting was the one stat that everyone stacked. Fighting was #1 on pets, most omega points, and even some artifacts. I don't think the update hurt artifact or unique diversity at all. My biggest gripe with the update is probably the Infinity system. While it does have some choice, it is nowhere near as indepth as the previous omega system. I also still do not like the fact that it is "infinite". It just reminds of Diablo's paragon system, and the paragon system has so many issues. Stacking stats endlessly is not something I agree with. Sure, there is slightly more diversity here, but it's not enough, and you will eventually end up taking everything anyway. It either needs more nodes, or a limit on how many points you can invest into each category. If the game continues as it is, this is going to be a huge nightmare for end game balancing. This leads me to what I believe have been the biggest issue that this game has had over the last year or so. The endgame and general gameplay have so many issues. When I joined, I was excited about the aspect of raids in this game, and red raid and green axis were somewhat tough at first. They got so much easier as time progressed and better items and heroes came out. It didn't help that no harder raid content ever came out. Gaz initially promised red axis and more raids, but those were thrown out in favor of more public zones and event areas. There is no reason to party with your friends outside of raids, because the only objective of terminals is to rush to the boss and kill him within one rotation. Even public zones don't really require a party outside of completing daily objectives because there are either too many people, or you could just solo the boss. As I've said before, there's no reason to kill non-boss mobs because they just don't drop anything worth picking up 99% of the time. There are so many outdated game modes that just don't offer too many rewards at the time. Even a public zone like industry city, which was new when I came back to the game, is not worth going into because it just doesn't offer much compared to midtown or hightown. Outside of somewhat rare danger room competitions or events, there just isn't much reason to switch up builds or play different heroes. It's been a long time since anything in this game has required you to party up with friends and fight something difficult. Oh well, I've ranted enough. Testing out new builds and combinations is fun for now, but the game has a long way to go before it's going to grab my attention for any significant amount of time again. If anyone actually managed to drag themselves through this wall of text, thanks for listening to my rant about how a game I loved has slowly been dyiing for over a year. This update is just disappointing and fixes few things.

content:
ber 28, 2016
												A great concept brought into the Marvel Universe. It's like a cross between World of Warcraft & Marvel: Future Fight (Mobile Game). I'm glad they chose to include heroes from both the X-Men universe, Avengers universe, Fantastic4 universe and lastly other heroes that you might not know even existed unless you read Marvel comics. It had a really great cinematic introduction at the start, like all other games do, but afterwards the rest of the storyline are being told like you're reading a comic book with audio, which is a really unique take into a game that has a storyline. This is, also most likely the first game I've seen so far that is MMO + a storyline behind it. However, the game can be further improved if even more heroes are added, and I'm really happy about the "choose any hero to play until lv 10". But, I'm really disappointed with the fps issue that I'm receiving from a game like this, and I have to play on Medium quality or lower, but sometimes I still get choppy frames. Of course the game runs smoothly, but there are times when it lags out or freezes especially when you're at a Hub, due to the high traffic. Also, I hope a more opened-world can be added, as the game feels like a board game, and also if we could rotate our camera, as when I zoom in to my character to make it more realistic, I can hardly see where I am going.Overall, a really good game, and it has improved a lot since it officially first came out, as I did came across this game when it first came out, but had many doubts on it and saw many bad reviews on it. I'll edit the review as I progress throughout the game, and hopefully some of the common bugs commented by other players can be fixed in a upcoming update(s) soon. I'm rating it 8/10P.S. use deadpool because he is OP

content:
9, 2016
The short version: Fun MMO/ARPG/Loot Dropper (Diablo, Torchlight, Sacred, Path of Exile, etc) game with a Marvel skin that's free to play (F2P) and pay to look good. Fun and pretty good about in game purchases.In DetailAt this point, I've played two characters (Cable & Dr. Strange) fairly extensively but not to max level and some of the others up to the level 10 cap. You can of course pay (either real money or time gated in game currency) to uncap other characters and it seems worthwhile to do so (the slow free option does anyway) since every character I've played has felt different from the others even if they function the same way. There also isn't the overused tank, dps, support character type mechanic which for me is a plus (though some characters are definitely tankier than others).Being F2P, there are of course some things that you can't get (or are very unlikely to get) without paying real money. Unlike many games with this monetization scheme, it doesn't really bother me as most of what's on offer is cosmetic or a variation on something you can get through other means and isn't pushed too hard (at least so far).The gameplay itself is repetitive but fun. You'll take on hordes of enemies, most of which will die from a single shot if you're playing an area at level, with a few tougher ones thrown in for something to use your powers on besides a boss. Difficulty varies depending on the character as some are significantly less durable than others, but this generally fits the character as expected and as long as you can keep an eye on your health while fighting actually dying is a rarity.On the whole, I'd recomend it as an F2P title since it doesn't have any "pay to win" mechanics that I've seen (yet) and is fun to play, especially with friends.I'll probably update this review when/if I reach Lvl 60 and see what the end game is like.

content:
15
												TL;DRFun Factor: 6/10 (for the first few hours)Gameplay: 7/10 (for the first few hours)Overall: 3/10 (After the first few hours)For anyone whom has never played the game before and is thinking about trying it out:CONS:- I'm 16 hours into the game and managed to go from level 1 to 60. And it got really boring getting there.- The game doesn't really teach you how to play it...? So you're just kind of overwhelmed the whole time.- There are not a whole lot of guides online for this game so you're kind of on your own. The ones I did find were apparently outdated and didn't even show the right information (such as the skill trees, talents, etc).- It's fun just to play the game off and on. You'll find it to be extremely repetitive and a lot of the side quests are not very informative on what you should do. It's like the game is missing map markers for those quests or something.- Some heroes are extremely underpowered compared to others. I got lucky when I chose Iron Man.- Expect to pay at least $20 USD to unlock a hero and level it past level 10 unless you farm for a week to get the ingame currency to unlock the hero yourself.- The huge number of different stats take a long time to sort of understand and getting an idea of what your hero needs to be stacking stats-wise is pretty much impossible unless you read A LOT online.- Fighting becomes extremely cookie-cutter by the time you reach level 20. After that you're just hitting the same buttons in the same order for every single fight...- 99% of the time I played with chat completely disabled because I saw that everything being said was total cancer. I guess that goes for most games. Out of those 16 hours I said a total of 2 words and that was "You're welcome." after helping someone.PROS:- Somewhat addicting for the first few hours as you explore the different heroes.- Fighting is fun and unique at first.- It's cool to fight the various villans and blow stuff up. It gets old, but it's fun at first.- Definitely play with the game sounds on, the voice lines from other heroes as yourun past them are pretty funny.And that's all I've got for PROS. I'm pretty much scaping the bottom of the bucket at this point.

content:
28, 2016
												This game is a blast!  I played at launch and wasn't too impressed.  However, since then they have made many improvements and added a ton of heroes.  I will list the PROS and CONS from my experience so far:PROS* Plays great on even lower end hardware* Graphics are surprisingly good.  The character models aren't amazing, but the spell/power effects and such are a lot of fun to look at.* Combat is fun and fast-paced.  Some issues will be listed in CONS.* Hero build diversity is the cornerstone to this game IMHO.  Each hero is its own distinct class.  How many ARPGs out there have so many classes??  And they're from the Marvel universe to boot!* Story is comic-style and pretty fun.  It isn't really required for more playthroughs, but fun the first time.* MOST content is obtainable via ingame currency.  You can earn heroes and most good stuff if you play enough and play smart.  There is something here for casual and hardcore min/maxers alike.* Heroes can be played for free to level 10.  Then you can pick 1 for a free unlock.  So much better than it was earlier in the game's lifespan.CONS* It can be a little overwhelming and complex for new players.  I suggest checking Youtube for new players, especially those new to the ARPG genre.  Wilfred Wong is my favorite presenter on there as he explains things well, while still having some endgame knowledge for those looking to optimize.  Don't look to him for min-max, but he's a very nice guy and worth a look for beginner/intermediate players.* Inventory is insane.  You need to really understand what is and isn't worth keeping, which will take time.  If you have a large roster of heroes, it is EXTREMELY difficult to avoid having to buy space from Gazillion.  But, the game is free, so I personally don't mind paying for something, it's fun afterall.* Like any MMO-style ARPG, open world content can be a little nuts.  It's usually a zerg race to bosses/quest targets, as better geared players can melt down just about anything in a couple seconds or so.  But respawn isn't terrible and you can get what you need if you watch the map.TLDR: It's a fun game for Marvel fans and ARPG fans alike.  I say give it a little time if you feel overwhelmed with it all.  Check the Youtube I mentioned and hope you have fun!!!

er 28, 2014
												I am not a fan of this genre. That is why I was so totally surprised when I really enjoyed this game. It's a blast! The heroes are really what makes this game shine. They all have their own attitudes and the writers do a good job of making their lines fit each of the heroes. A lot of the heroes play similarly to each other but they have enough of their own flavor to stand on their own. This game has a wonderful cash shop. The whole game is playable for free and you can earn currency to purchase heroes. This is a game I have been willing to put money into because the cash shop is so fair. It boils down to buffs, costumes, and heroes if you don't want to wait to get the ones you want. Gazillion has done a great job of introducing heroes with incredible frequency and even heroes that a lot of people feel are underpowered are still totally viable for leveling if they are a character that you feel strongly about. You can't go wrong trying this game out.

content:
r 8, 2014
												Being a very very very picky gamer, I actually love this game. I used to play Dream of Mirror Online. I like anime/cartoon style games and this satisfies my taste fully. I'm especially a Marvel fan, growing up with every action figure known to exist and collecting comics and really love that this game brings heroes and villains that I haven't seen in years to life!! It may sound uber geek, but when I first fought Mr. Sinister, I think I may have yelped like, "oh snap, I had him as a toy when I was a kid!" Now next to nostalgic reasons for playing this game, I'll list below the reasons why I actually love the gameplay and content.This game doesn't have a really tough grind to level up to 60 scale. It's fairly easy but fun in the process as you learn so many mechanics that are built into the game. From designing the build that best suits the skills you like to use, to hunting for unique items and skill combinations that work best. It's a great game. As far as content is concerned, there has been a weekly event each week I've played so far and the release of new Heroes and Teamup Heroes. The devs at Gazillion are putting forth effort to revise characters that may need a review suggested by players of the game from what I can tell. It's very well balanced and has many different angles to play the game which keeps it fresh.The characters in the game are many, which is great and once you level up to 60 you can Prestige your character up to Prestige 6. The more heroes you bring up to 60 the bigger experience bonuses you get to help level other heroes you get. It's not a pay to win game as anything in the game can be purchased by playing the game and saving up. I willingly purchased inventory space and a costume because I found one of my favorite characters to play with, Dr. Strange!!All in all, I suggest giving this game a shot as the community is very helpful and fun to chat with. This is by far the best game I've played in a long time and so much to learn and do in the game, I can't seem to put it down and do homework! lol Again the community freakin' rocks!! So yea I'm not sure about other reviews and they're gripe with the game but the ones that play and are in-game love it. Try it for yourself and make your own educated decision :)

content:
er 25, 2013
												First off, it's an ARPG not an MMO, so don't go thinking it's WOW with Marvel characters. Secondly, your customisation options are very limited - it's a Marvel game and they're ferociously protective of their characters' images, so apart from the preset costumes you're basically limited to cosmetic effects like glowing auras, you can't customise your characters' appearance to any real degree.In terms of gameplay, it's a pretty solid Diablo clone, the different characters all play sufficiently differently to each other to make it interesting, and you can unlock all the characters for free if you're patient enough. There's some things you can't earn ingame - such as additional bank slots - and some like costumes which you can theoretically earn in game, but the drop rates are absolutely terrible. But it's just cosmetic and quality-of-life stuff which you need to buy, if you don't mind a bit of grinding you can unlock everything else without paying anything.Ultimately it comes down to how much of a Marvel fan you are - there are better ARPGs on the market, but none of them have such a strong brand behind them, and if you're even a casual fan of the comics, cartoon series or films, being able to play as the characters will probably be all the counragement you need. And if you're still not sure, it's competely free to play with no restrictions on what free players can access, so you may as well give it a go and see for yourself whether you like it.

content:
er 27, 2013
												Marvel Heroes is the absolute average of average with nothing actually going for it, and is simply riding on the theme which is its one redeeming quality. The fact that Marvel Heroes is an MMO and a F2P one at that, heavily undermines the actual experience. The story is neither interesting nor boring – nor is it hero specific giving you little replay reasons, and you won’t ever get immersed into your character. The way they handle F2P means they want you to buy costumes – for ridiculous amounts of money, and as a result gear is absolutely boring and you’ll look like almost every other hero out there. Had Marvel Heroes not been an online F2P game, had this been an on- and offline game with a one-time purchase, I could see this being a ton more enjoyable and worth playing. Or even simply allowing you to pick from any of the super heroes on the list at the start, while pricing them all the same, would have been far more reasonable.As it stands, Marvel Heroes is boring in its combat, boring as a loot hunting game and boring as an immersive experience with an incredibly unfair microtransaction system. content:
7, 2014
												What do you get when you take the base gameplay/advancement system of diablo 2, spend another year developing end game content, and wrap it all up inside a skin of Marvel Superheroes? You get an excellent game, that's what! The game is truly free-to-play requiring nothing to be spent for anything in the game (except time played if you want to buy more heroes). Of course like any good f2p game you can optionally spend money to buy exactly what you want when you want it. No matter what though, either way you approach Marvel Heroes 2015 you are in for a treat. The only real downside to the game is the same downside to every single ARPG. I gets VERY grindy at the end. Fortunately rather than just grinding the end-game indefinitely, new heroes (classes) are released every single month. On top of that so far a handful of new game modes have been added every few months or so as well. For fans of ARPGs, and especially those looking for a f2p game that doesn't feel or play like you would expect a f2p title to feel/play, Marvel 2015 gets a VERY easy recommendation.

												After playing through the story mode and leveling my first hero up, I figured I'd post a review. I thoroughly enjoy this game. It's made by the original creators of Diablo and Diablo II so it has that feel to it, which works surprisingly well in the Marvel universe. Although a lot of the content can be paid for to unlock, you can also earn 90% of it in-game, without having to spend a dime. It's pretty well balanced, so that it doesn't take a ridiculously long time to earn something. You don't feel like your hand is being twisted to buy things with real money, which is a breath of fresh air in games like this. The graphics are above average, if you don't have a decent PC it will struggle a little bit. The gameplay is pretty much identical to Diablo and similar action RPG games. There's a lot to this game I could spend hours talking about, but overall I would definitely recommend it. After all it's free.

												Imagine "Diablo 2: Lord of Destruction;" but with Marvel characters and an MMO-style gameplay.F2P to me is normally like this;"There's a catch. I have to pay millions." - BUT!This game is nothing like that. It's very rewarding and totally free; but you're gonna have to be a sucker for grinding, loving Marvel and also if Diablo 2 was one of your favorite games back in the day, then this game is perfect.The game has a lot to offer, but it's very confusing since no one is holding your hand like in most other games. You have to learn and also adapt to the game; it won't adapt to you. Pick your free hero out of the entire roster of heroes - except the newest one, they're always locked as a "new hero" until the next new hero is released - once you get your favorite hero. Play. Understand. Adapt! You'll also get 400 Eternity Splinters for free after your second day login, which you can use to buy another free hero and you won't have to pay for any new ones unless you want to.It's great fun and very addicting! :)Thumbs up from me!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												This game has problems, most of them quite boring.So let's talk about the interesting problem, immersion.In a universe where players can control the Hulk yet are still mortal, can be Iron Man or Thor yet need to walk around iron fences in their path or be Spiderman yet never have a convoluted dance sequence, there is something wrong.Having players be the big-name heroes is the main appeal of the game, but also its main problem since they must be weaker than they should be.The fact that there are thousands of Spider Men players walking around is explained by Doctor Doom breaking reality, and honestly the source material is sufficiently out there that it actually works, but Vision being knocked out by half a dozen of street thugs just breaks immersion.The solution? Pick somebody that doesn't really have super powers, which in my case was Black Widow.Suddenly things felt a lot nicer. Overcoming challenges felt more in line with the character, and beating a C-List villain after a long boss battle feels satisfying instead of weird.So, if you try out the game, do yourself a favour and pick a character that "shouldn't" be that strong, and you'll have a far better time.Beyond that very specific gripe it's a decent, if very, very run of the mill isometric MMORPG. There's a decent main plot, tons of barely distinguishable loot, a pile of monetization mechanics (but no "stamina" or avoidable revive penalty or something, so it's not quite that bad).As a free game it's worth a look, whether you stick with it is very much dependent on your resistance to tedium.

Gazillion continues to impress with regular updates, featuring my favorite characters from the Marvel Universe, and keeping the content fresh and exciting.  You can get a little OCD with this game as every character is unique, fun to play, rewarding in different ways... and you'll find yourself wanting to collect and play them all.  And if you have a few dollars to throw their way you are rewarded with cool perks, new costumes, and upgrades that don't leave you feeling like it is "pay to win."  Looking forward to more from this game in the coming months.  A fan.

number of helpful: 60 of 112 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Do you enjoy the loot fest of Diablo? Do you wish Torchlight 2 had a constant community to interact with ingame? Do you enjoy Path of Exile, but sometimes want an easier and less hardcore experience? Then Marvel Heroes might be your go to game this summer!Don't let reviewers shy you away from the game because a lot of its problems from last June have been fixed (mostly). The game does still have its problems and shortcomings. As of writing this they still do not have a proper trade menu, which every MMO ever has gotten right if they were made in the past decade. Characters are imbalanced but a lot of the free starter characters offer fun diverse playstyles. After completing story mode you'll be offered the ability to get another free one. Heroes are no longer random drops, but rather awarded to you for playing long periods of time. The only real thing that only money can buy is storage space.Yes this game is not as great as Dota2 or Path of Exile at the Free2Play Model, but it isn't the worst anymore. All heroes have been marked down since the original release and are (for the most part) priced fairly for the amount of time a person invests in the hero. There's also a server called Test Center that allows you to test out a character at the max level, to see if you'll enjoy the character before ever buying them. Something that was a major problem at the game's initial release. Honestly the game has come a long way since last June. However the lack of a trade system, quickly running into inventory management, no autosort option for items, weird chat UI, and lack of partying incentive during the grind from 1 to 60... really holds the game back from being a major recommendation. However if you're a fan and want to try a new Diablo style lootfest, Marvel Heroes might be worth your time.

												Pros+ARPG like Torchlight/PoE/Diablo+Marvel Super Heroes!+Comic lore+So many characters to choose from+You dont need to buy anything to play effectively. +Raids!+Endless wave modes like X-defense and Midtown!+SO MUCH LOOT!+Plenty of endgame content+The Developers are dedicated everyday to making this game better and always adding more content! Cons-Needs more optimization.-Sometimes there are little glitches within the story scenes, but easy to overcome.-Not enough room for items considering all the characters in the game that is free. You have to buy the extra spaces for more storage, but its not that bad of a price I guess, considering how you play.-No real punishment when your character dies. I guess that would be aimed towards the casual player vs the hardcore?-Some character balancing issues, but most often fixed. So I guess its nothing to get worried about too much. -Crafting is not the greatest, but its there. Yay for options! -Trade system needs a lot of work. Totally worth the FREE! Very good game for the Marvel fans! Gazillion has done a superb job on delivering a really good videogame. Overall, a really enjoyable experience.

content:
14, 2016
												Boy, did they turn this game around! I played this game when it first came out, and even though it was OK, it didn't impress me that much. However, I heard TotalBiscuit recommend the current version a LOT, he basically rediscovered the game and was playing it a ton. And, well, I tried it and was hooked quickly, and the improvements made to the game ever since it was launched make it a LOT better. So, basically, this is a Diablo-type game, kinda "Diablo in the Marvel Universe". However, IMO, the game makes you feel much more powerful than Diablo ever does. You will run into screens absolutely filled with mobs, and then commence to blow up that screen with your powers. There is tons of loot, and inventory space can become an issue, so I recommend to set the option to auto-destroy grey and white gear. You can also level your pet by "vacuuming" up gear you don't need, and you wanna donate a ton of gear to level crafters for better item mods etc. Anyway... the game is SO much fun. It's not deep or anything, it's basically "run around and blow up everything". But gosh, you DO feel powerful. It's a blast. Each character really is different, plays differently. You have ranged guys like Cyclops or Hawkeye, each with different abilities, or you can smash enemies as Hulk or Colossus etc. It's quite impressive how they came up with that many different character-abilities and "styles", as they actually DO feel a lot different. Example: Both Cyclops and Iron Man can be specced for long range fighting (or melee), and they do feel different, so it's not just "two ranged guys who just look different".Even more off-beat chars like Ant-Man are cool, that one is a personal favorite, and so is Deadpool, who is, appropriately, totally bonkers. The game actually IS F2P. You can play for free, and when you start, you can choose ONE character to level beyond level 10 (you can play most characters to level 10 at any time). You can unlock more characters by grinding for Eternity Splinters, or buy them at the store for ingame-currency. If you are into cosmetics, you can buy several very cool or even legendary costumes for those chars (esp. Iron Man, Cyclops, Spiderman, Cap etc.). However, those are cosmetic, so this is not "P2W" or anything. I am not much into the endgame, so I am just having a blast running around with some of the characters I have loved since childhood, enjoying playing them a lot, regardless of which one is best for endgame or whatever. Sure, the game can be grindy, but it is very alt-friendly. Each char you level unlocks special perks (you can choose which ones you use) for your alts, and leveling speeds up the more you level your characters. You can either play the story-mode, grind the legendary quest and challenges, or simply do stuff like "Monday Midtown Madness", which is a rush.I am not sure whether this is the kind of game you wanna "binge-play". I love to play it for an hour or so each day to blow off some steam, get my mind off of things. As I said, it's not terribly deep, but terrific fun, so it's a great game to just run around and blow up thousands of mobs. And- if you are a Marvel-fan, this is like paradise.So many iconic characters and costumes (like from classic comic issues, or the Ultimate series, or the movies etc.), so many references to the comics... just amazing. If you are into Diablo-type games, give this a try. If you are into Marvel, same. If you are into both, knock yourself out, I am pretty positive you will enjoy the heck out of this. Performance is good, even though slower PCs might struggle with screens full of mobs and explosions. Loving it, and big kudos to the dev team for turning this into a much better game and putting so much fun stuff and so much Marvel-lore into this. Just... FUN!Pros:- Great variety of heroes, which all feel different- Lots of Marvel lore- Nice visual style- Actual F2P. You have to grind for more heroes, but you CAN, even without investing money (unless we talk about inventory)- FUN- Great performance even with gazillion mobs on screen on a decent PC- Lots of events and references to current comics and movies- Solo-friendly if you prefer that- Alt-friendly (VERY)Cons:- Inventory space will run out VERY VERY quickly. Your heroes share bank-and bag-space. If you wanna collect relics and legendaries, crafting mats and items you might use later (some items are char-specific, some can be used by any char), you will most likely have to buy more space. This is the only money I invested here. - Can be grindy, YMMV- Some quests might be bugged. COuldnt complete chapter 1 yet because of a symbiote mission in a police HQ

content:
y 20
												I've used the -nosteam shortcut so Steam only shows hours played for when I've launched via Steam to purchase G's at times and DLC's, but I've 600 days played, all the Heros, geared, had max Omega Points (10K), and the game used to be so much fun!We had freedom of movement, good damage output to help us through tougher content, an Omega System that, while a bit complicated at first, did it's job despite some issues, some essential life-saver items (Invul for those stupid 1-shot mechanics bosses have), multiple power bars to give us the ability to use a good variety of powers (Dr Strange players have probably quit already now we've just one bar!).Now... teleports that are slower to get to position than dashes are and both teleports and dashes are limited to 3 times before you need to stop and catch your breath for a few seconds, and travel powers that have a charge-up time before you even start moving.  An 'Infinity' system that limits your choices of where to spend points by splitting their allocation down amongst different types.  Severely nerf'd damage output and reduced defense against damage taken.  One power bar, one, to fit a very limited number of powers in out of the 20odd each Hero has.  Slow, clunky, tedious gameplay.There were so many people on the forum basically begging the div'elopers not to go through with most of these changes but got ignored, as a company they've always been a bit arrogant but they went above and beyond their usual.  And good luck posting anything on their forum, one of their moderators is a total moron who's first language clearly is not English due to how he dishes out warnings for innocent threads that he doesn't understand.This, when first announced, felt to me like it was purely being done to dumb the game down for consoles and now there's zero doubt that's the reason.As for recommending the game, I can't anymore.  I'm struggling to find motivation to play and what little I have is due to having put a lot of money in to the game over the years.  However, everyone is different and you 'may' enjoy it in it's new 'Nerf Heroes' format, but not so likely.

												Marvel Heroes is essentially Ultimate Alliance 3 with a more Diablo bent. There's a large cast of characters and they're all different.  You have to start with one though, but the game gives you a nice starter roster. I've been playing as Punisher and its been real fun. Other characters cost money or you need to find a certain amount of in-game items to purchase them by beating the campaigns or by enemy drops so you best stick with a character you'll like unless you want to put in the time or money. Really its not a big deal though because the Free to Play elements are well utilized in the sense that you can just casually enjoy the whole game without spending a dime. Definitely worth playing, and because its free you have no reason not to.

												Marvel Heroes won't win any prizes for originality, but it is an extremely fun game in its own right that makes effective use of the license at its disposal, and it's always refreshing to encounter a free-to-play title that is intended to be precisely that.You can play Marvel Heroes through without spending any money on it, and it will be a decent experience for you. However, the inelegant handling of multiple characters, along with the lack of any real difficulty means that it doesn’t quite reach the heights of other games in the genre. But it is the only game of its type where you can play as your favourite Marvel characters and that is certainly something that will draw many people in.

												At launch, Marvel Heroes was a huge mess.But since then, the game has improved by leaps and bounds. Constant updates, hero reworks, new game modes, special events.... I´m actually having a lot of fun playing it!There´s a large selection of heroes and they play/feel different enough to make you want to unlock multiple heroes.The free to play model is fair... you can unlock every heroe just by playing, although it takes a ridiculous amount of time.Only things you can´t unlock by just playing are extra bank space and some costumes for your heroes.If you enjoy action rpgs, Marvel Heroes is worth taking a look at.The game is fun to play, looks good, animations are well done, the devs are very active on the forums, the community is very nice and helpfull and heck, you get to play 30+ different heroes from the Marvel Universe.Granted, if mindlessly killing waves upon waves of mobs looking for loot is not your cup of tea, this might not be the game for you. But if you are looking for a game to fill the void left by the trainwreck that was Diablo 3 and don´t feel like dealing with Path of Exile over complicated talent tree and (IMO) ugly graphics, Marvel Heroes provides a good, satisfying time for casual players.

content:
22, 2014
												Marvel Heroes ReviewMarvel Heroes launch wasn’t the best but has definitely changed from an average game to a fun and enjoyable game. Marvel Heroes has a large roster of heroes to choose from and while you can acquire them through micro-transactions it is completely optional, you can get all the heroes through collecting “eternity splinters” which you can trade them off for heroes of your choice. While getting heroes can be done at the cost of nothing, getting “fancy” new costumes for your heroes does cost money. Marvel Heroes has a large storyline which you can play through and the developers constantly add more and more chapters, might I say you can play through the whole storyline for free if you’re wondering. Marvel Heroes is if you haven’t guessed yet is a lot like Diablo so if you’re a fan of that game and a fan of marvel then this game is perfect for you. There are lots to do in Marvel Heroes from occasional events, players vs. players and lots of different things you can do after you have finished the story. Overall Marvel Heroes is a well made game and because it’s free, there is no reason not to try it out.

												The game is masterful.  There are tons of characters to choose from and it is put together with David Brevik at the helm.  Gazillion is the most active development team with the community right now and I love the effort they are putting into this game.  This game was horrible when it first launched and now, it is incredibly good.  If you're wondering if this game is for you, ask yourself if you loved Diablo 2.  That's what this game is trying to become and it's getting closer and closer with each patch.  I'm much older now than when I was a teenager playing Diablo 2 and even I wondered if this would scratch that nostalgic itch.  For me, it did and it is my favorite game out right now.  I'm not a comic reader and don't follow anything in Marvel at all, but I just love this game.  It's my perfect ARPG and I can't wait to see how it progresses over time.  I'd recommend this game to ANY ARPG fan out there since it's free and it's only getting better.

												My true number of hours is not right, i've got a few hundred in reality with 15 different 50+ characters and i have to say, after all that time casually playing this game and now, with this update, im done. This update is complete trash, the characters have been over-simplified into cookie-cutter toons that makes me feel im playing a mobile device game and not on my PC. Where once all characters could be tweeked thanks to the infiity system and points spent into skills, now you jsut have a few traits and talents to choose from (15 different power modifers, once chosed at each tier). What once was a robust post 60 skill tree in the Omega system is now a rigid, restrictive Infinity system with little choice in comparison. it feels like someone in corporate development thought to key into the movie franchise and try to draw a connection, and in the process trashed the game. I do hope that someone in the halls of gazillion reads these posts and says to themselves "We made a mistake".

												Clearly this game need a re-rate!! After stopping for sometime, decided to load it up and see what is new :) glad i did. this game is very well a gem at the moment. It has a bad launch with un-optimised engine, bad contents, bad special effects, bad balance, junk inventory items (e.g. crafting items). Just bad of everything. I actually managed to get few friends to play with me during that time. All left with a bad taste in the mouth after a week or two. It was because of the inventory hog and has the feeling that developer just wants you to spend on the F2P game. Now all of these crafting items are more managable with stacking. but somehow they have reintroduced another inventory hog- Relics.. sigh.. There are now a lot more things to do in the game and more items to collect for you hero item slots. Also lots of modes has been introduced. Midtown Mahanthan is just brilliant. You can be in there the whole day clearing the mobs there. mobs are also more varied than it used to be. There is also Heroic and more difficlt modes for you to relive the story mission and get better equipments.There are lots more contents but i am no real reviewer.. :p i would give this a 80/100 for what it is now.Be going back to my marvel game now..

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2014
												First off, don't let the Metacritic rating scare you off.  Everyone who played it at launch fully admits that the game was ♥♥♥ on toast then.  Currently, Marvel Heroes is a fantastic ARPG well worth looking at.Unlike a lot of ARPGs that have come down the pike since Diablo 2, what the devs at Gazillion rightly realize is that the reason that D2 was so beloved was that it's just plain fun to mow down gigantic hordes of mooks like a hot knife through butter, slowing down only to sort your loot or focus on a boss (or four).  The source material fits perfectly with this gameplay - of course Iron Man or Hulk can smash through absurdly large numbers of foes without breaking a sweat, something would be wrong if they couldn't.Couple this with attack effects as flashy as you'd expect from comic books (and the fact that you can't help blowing up/breaking virtually everything in sight) and it's basically the perfect ARPG for the ADD set.Moreover, Marvel Heroes is massively generous as a free to play game; you've got 9 different characters to choose from at start and every single character in the game can be unlocked for free just by playing the game.  Sure, you can buy characters with money if you want but don't feel like you have to in order to play the game, most of the starters are perfectly viable.  The only thing that absolutely can't be gotten via just playing is extra stash space, but by the time you've played long enough to really need/want more you'll probably have gotten enough entertainment value to lay down a few bucks.Gazillion is a developer that patches and updates the game incredibly often (sometimes too often, but they're getting better) and they're fantastic with communicating with the playerbase.  New heroes are coming out pretty much every month.This is not the hardest ARPG around, and it can get a bit repetitive at times, but it's well worth checking out and a lot of fun.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Marvel Heroes combines two of my favorite things, Diablo's "Kill things get loot." formula and the Marvel Universe. For the new player you make your account and you're given a selection of starting heroes to start you out in your adventures in this Diablo style MMO. These nine heroes are Luke Cage, The Punisher, Captain America, Black Panther, Black Widow, Human Torch, Colossus, Storm, and Hawkeye. All of which have their strengths and weaknesses. From here you load into the game and are started on your first run through of the story. In honesty the story isn't outstanding, but it's written in true Marvel fashion and has the good ol' Super hero fun. You play as your hero who starts out in midtown New York doing his/her hero thing when they get a call from Jocasta stating that Nick Fury needs your help. Hydra ((Most recently depicted in the recent Winter Solider movie)) is up to their usual shinnagins and is attempting to break out super powered villains from The Raft. A Famous Marvel Universe prison designed to contain super villains. From there you go places across the universe and aid various factions all while be treated to voice acted comic slides that progress the story.Additional heroes are unlocked through ether the cash shop for various prices or by collecting "Eternity Splinters" which can be a grind but you'll spend at least 60 or so hours leveling your starting hero to the cap of sixty. this brings me to what impresses me most about this free to play game. The only things that require real money is buying additional tabs for your storage, buying the exact character costume you want and certain consumables. ((Some of these are quest rewards that you can gain three times per hero, one for each difficulty.)) Other then that everything is completely obtainiable ((Albet some of it extremely rare)) within the game's normal playing. Random costumes can drop or be crafted at your crafter once you level him up for example! Well I hope those who read this decide to give the game a shot!

												Great, a slightly below average quality marvel "RPG" that has 90% of its content stuck behind nearly $300 dollars of DLC. thanks. I mean who would want an actual Marvel RPG with custome characters and well a integrated story that makes us want to play as much as possible? DC got pretty close with DC universe which i dont even think exists anymore. This game is a blatent cash grab, and while i understand its a company that needs to keep up a profit, they dont seem to have tried at all with this game. it feels like one of those crappy JRPG's that you find on the adds on the side of random websites. they advertise it as "the best thing ever" and when you play it its just a basic template with differant assets pasted on top. see, if the DLC's were $2 or even $5 i wouldnt have an issue, thats a reasonable price. but prices from $12 to $40 for a few characters, some costumes, and some in game boosts is insulting. its like every bit of DLC is the price that the whole game plus all of the DLC should cost. if the game were $40 and had all the DLC in it i would be perfectly ok with it.

content:
9, 2015
												More 'maybe' than yes. Read on to find what I mean by that.(NOTE: this is more 'what you need to know about Marvel Heroes' than a review.It includes tips, info, & me explaining features of the game. If you want in-depth pros & cons, there are other reviews for that. thanks.)OverviewMarvel Heroes MIGHT be worth you checking out. I have 'played' this game for 415 hours so far, but I have a hard time recommending it unless you...1. like...marvel's heroes A LOT & 2. have a friend or 2 that will play it with you sometimes.3. have means/money you can add to your Steam account when the time comes Basically it's a fun Action-RPG BASED ON BEING (A) CERTAIN CHARACTER(S).IF you enjoy being said character & don't care too much about level design or story, then you will enjoy this for its gameplay and FEELING LIKE said character(s).but you have to have really good self control. The game rewards you with Eternity Splinters that let you buy/unlock more characters. The main negative is you will be tempted to buy a lot of things with real money (in currency called 'G') -especially more STASH- OR you will constantly have to clear out your storage spaces (which is what I do all the time always, even though as-of this review, I have 9 STASH's +3 character-specific STASH's). The upside is they are constantly updating it, adding playable characters, events, team-ups, etc.Key Features to knowBODYSLIDE: this is a teleport that takes you back to a HUB at any time. It has a cooldown of 10 minutes. It can be used twice before the cooldown starts: once to take you to the hub and once to take you back (to the spot you bodyslid from).ULTIMATE: every character has an Ultimate power/skill. To my knowledge, they all unlock at Lvl 52 (max lvl is 60). The cooldown for the ultimate starts at 10 minutes (but you can put points into it to be less).key TIPS to know:you have to LEVEL YOUR CRAFTER (by donating items to it): this is just a tip, but it's an annoying thing considering much of the early game you are left wishing your crafter was a higher level, but all the crafter is really good for IMO is tranfering an item over to another character. And also for upgrading blue gear to purple.You get a LOT of LOOT: So plan accordingly. Until you get a 2nd stash, I wouldn't even think of getting a 2nd character, but that's just my advice. Once you get a 2nd STASH, then you can start another character, maybe even 2 if you can handle limited storage.there are a LOT of different items in this game, including artifacts, costume cores, 'crafting items' (4 different types with 8 different tiers for each), boost potions, pets, rings, runes (used in crafting with URU gear), URU gear (1 wearable per character, can't wear until Lvl 25), medals, medallions, and a few more I can't think of now.*update1 [05/13/2015]* - I feel I should mention the cost of things in this game*update2 [06/18/2015]* added in 'crafting tab'  to pricing list below, & its price/value/usefulness*update3 [07/04/2015]* added introduction to try to better explain my goal of this 'review.'PRICINGSTASH (regular) : 500 G ($5.00)Character-specific STASH : 350 G ($3.50)Crafting Tab: 200 G ($2.00)^The first 2 are the main 2 tabs you should ever 'NEED' to buy in this game.I recently realized how valuable crafting tabs are later in the game, since I had a TON of runestones and crafting items that can be stashed there. I didn't know Runes (aka. runestones) were allowed in that stash, but NOW that I do, I think they are a good deal if you have 4 or more rows of runes sitting around (that you don't want to get rid of).That said, MH only lets you buy Gs in 'bundles', otherwise known as lump sums.There is 500 G bundle, 1000 G bundle, 2100 G bundle ($20), and so on.This is an annoying model and I dislike it very much, but what can you do about it?The only thing I will say in DEFENSE of this model is the fact that it's KIND-OF like a subscription fee...only you actually get something in return, and if you look at it that way, it's not so bad. Especially since you are NOT forced to pay anything to play this game.---------TL; DR= if you have a friend playing this with you, & you like a certain Marvel hero a lot, try it.....if you have no money to buy anything, you probably DON'T want to try it, because you will be muy (very) frustrated.***********POST-SCRIPT. ADDED 11/15/2015*Originally I rated this game a 'Yes', but now I definitely lean more towards no. Maybe my tastes have changed. maybe I've simply beat the game too many times. Maybe I haven't given the 'endgame' a decent try (I really haven't). but whatever the reason, I don't feel like playing this game anymore. :(

content:
y 5, 2014
												Well its been about 6 months since the last time I wrote a review on this game (gave it about a 5.7/10 as it had many flaws), and I recently just got back into Marvel Heroes and felt that it was appropriate to update my review on the game. Marvel Heroes as a game has grown a whole lot since its really bad release. Various numbers and formulas have changed for damage calculating, and heroes have been revamped (making OP heroes less OP while making the boring and weak heroes a hell of a lot more fun).Since my departure from the game, I can't say that a whole lot of content has been added, because it hasn't. However, end game content has been revised and the game as a whole gets better each week thanks to the Devs working really REALLY close with the community in terms of QA and asking the players how each Hero feels with each and every new patch that is released.In terms of the f2p of the game, the heroes arent as pricey, they are all much more acceptable with most of them costing less than 10 dollars, leaving a small few which include IronMan, Deadpool and Spider-Man (and maybe one or two more I cannot remember) costing around 12 bucks. With costumes still being roughly the same price they always were (varrying from 10 for the average skin and 20 for a Enhanced skin) as that is now their main source of revenue. But this is all because Heroes are much more easy to obtain in game now with the addition of a new currency that the player earns as they play overtime. With the currency players can now save up to purchase their desired hero (for varrying costs) or can opt-in for a much cheaper "gacha bag" option where the player buys a random hero at a reduced price.All in all I recommend checking out this game if you are at least a fan of ARPGs, its not quite on the same level as Torchlight 2 and Path of Exile just yet, however I have no doubt that it is getting there. If you don't believe me check out their weekly patch notes, its crazy how many things are changed each and everytime.7.6/10....for now!
