content:
ry 10, 2014
												So, maybe you've seen the metacritic review, maybe you played in the beta and never came back. What you would behold in these PoVs is what most people would say is an "okay but not great, still feels unpolished" ARPG featuring the Marvel cast. No one would blame you at all for putting it down, and simply walking away.But things got better.Oh my stars and garters things got better. Updated power trees, rebalanced heroes, a damn transfusion level injection of sustainability and playability! Seriously, I really have to commend gazillion for all that they've done with their game. It went from a ho-hum beat 'em up to a full realization of what expected at the beginning, and it's just getting better with every update.I will grant you, that updates aren't 100% complete, and some heroes still fill just a twinge undercooked (I'm looking at you Cyclops), but that said this is still, I feel, an absolute must-"buy" for fans of Marvel, Diablo (the first 2 at least), and co-op smashfests in general.Still not convinced? Well, it IS free....sooo.....it'll only cost you the download time and hard drive space.

												I don't really play this game currently but look at how many hours i wasted on it.Its free to play but i could have get a car with all the money i used on MH for the swag.Right now,my only concern is that even with the content they make,the characters don't feel as epic as they should. Most of the characters you can build however you want of course, but for good dps,there's are certain skillsets you have to use. Look at the official forums,and you'll see im right.If you end up getting rare items,then of course you can almost get away with lackluster builds.Now you might say,"why are you recommend the game but you're just saying negatives about it?"You got me there,but it's a free to play game, and there's a lot of content to pass the time.Lots of characters to unlock with splinters that you can acquire at a decent rate.That being said, there are downsides,but it's worth checking out considering the amount of content you get. Final verdict-I know I'll go back to this game down the road, but I'm waiting for a lot of serious changes before I do.You get incredible content for a free game,and you can't really pay to win in this one cause the pvp is dead anyways.8/10

												During the beta, the game was pretty bad, so I put it away. Came back to it recently after hearing about the changes and despite the stigma of a free to play... it is incredibly fun. You can unlock heroes without money in an expected amount of time. The hardest thing to do without spending money, is inventory control. You won't have access to a ton of inventory slots so you would need to be careful. But the game is worth 40 dollars. I had 50 hours in easy. No plan to stop. So throwing 10-20 bucks at later on for quality of life is a no brainer. I have paid a lot of more games that kept me a lot less entertained and of a much lower quality. Heroes is excellent. Beyond that, the crew that works on the game is amazing. The devs join in on streams, they listen to the community. We vote on new hero releases. It is definitely worth your time and if you want to definitely worth a couple dollars later on.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2014
												All of these negative reviews you see are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Don't listen to them. This is a wonderful game that is absolutely worth your time, especially if you're a fan of ARPGs such as Diablo, Torchlight, the Sacred series, etc.It plays EXACTLY like them, but in the Marvel universe, with marvel characters. And boy, are there a lot of characters to play as. There's over 40 I believe, and they just keep adding to that number semi-frequently. There are three difficulties to play. You start in normal mode, and as you complete the campaign mode, you'll unlock the other two. The higher difficulties will give you better loot drops, more gold, more experience, etc.This game has a lot of unique things going on that make it even more sensational. There's an omega system, which is basically paragon levels from D3, but it's really interesting, and there's a TON of variety, which in turn, makes customizing your character almost an endless affair. You can do so many things with one hero, it's amazing. There's this feature called "Team-ups" which I think are pretty cool as well. They're essentially pets, but in the form of other heroes that'll tag along with you. However, you can outfit them and customize their abilities as well, so it really adds even more depth to your ever-growing ARPG OCD :PThere's also PvP and group play, which is to be expected from an online game. Group play is pretty cool, as you'll drop down in an area and team up with nearby heroes to take down tough baddies. Don't worry though, there's no fighting over loot, it all drops seperately for each character. Honestly,  it's just great fun. If you love superheroes, if you love ARPGs, it's the perfect match for you. You can purchase every hero/team-up in the game for free. The currency, eternity splinters, drop frequently and a person is more than capable of not spending a dime on this game. That being said, you have nothing to lose, and I guarentee you'll have some fun if you give it a shot.

content:
2, 2014
												What other game do you get to play as Dr. Strange, Black Panther, and Nightcrawler, that's also penned by the legendary Brian Michael Bendis???  This game is f2p but you'll find that you need to drop around $20 to have a good time, which isn't bad considering I've spent $60 on crap games that I've barely touched. Although everything is unlockable by playing the game, so there really is no need to drop any money, but the drop rates are really low and the splinters (in game currency) take some time to farm. However considering I've sunk more time in this gem than about 98% of my game library, I don't mind throwing the developers a few nickles. Also the developers are always running promotions, updating content, adding new material, listening to feedback, and constantly improving the game. Bottomline, if you're a fan of Marvel or even like Diablo-esque click+loot+click games, then you owe it to yourself to check this "Thing" out (Eh, eh, see what I did there).

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												No Idea where people are getting some of their reviews from. must be playing a different game to me. Firstly Since release there has been alot of improvements to the game and plentry of content released. They tend to release a new playable Hero each month as well as weekly bug fixes and some other content such as weekend events etc. In terms of Content it is releasing PvP and Raids in Beta with Raids being out of Beta in a few weeks. Also other game modes are added such as X-Defense which is a wave based mode which was not implented on release. One Shot terminals which are small story arcs. Shared Quests that allow you to group up. Plus there is other stuff coming in the coming months such as Endless Dungeons.Now to the Free to Play part. People who say this is pay to win are clearly unaware that all heroes can be bought without spending a penny. Yes it will take time to earn but the game is by no means pay to win. the only thing you will need to purchase is bank space and even that is not a necesity if you can keep your inventory tidy and are willing to not horde items. Finally the Devs. Anyone who does go on the forums for this game will be aware of how active the devs are. They take alot of community feedback on board and try to gear the game to be enjoyed by the player. If your not a superhero fan then maybe this isnt for you as much but it is a great way to get into the universe of Marvel. Brilliant Game and Enjoyable for most ages in my opinion. 10/10 and best superhero game i have played

content:
y 10, 2015
												**PROS AND CONS BELOW INTRO**When Marvel Heroes first came out it was fun for awhile but I eventually got bored with it. With its new Marvel Heroes 2015 edition where they have been remaking/updating all the heroes with New 52 models, I just cant stop playing. It does remind me of the old days of getting home after school (at the time) and rushing to play Diablo 2 with my friends everyday. PROS:+Lots of Characters to Choose From+Many different playstyles to fit anyones prefered taste+Great Graphics, still good on even the lowest settings+Capable of Unlocking any Hero without having to pay+RUNEWORDS! (I loved Runewords from D2 lol)+Crafting/Enchanting+Lots of Fun Events by the Devs, especially during Marvel Movie Releases+Great Promos/Giveaways+Devs/GMs Actually listen to the players as a wholeCONS:-Public Maps can be VERY bad for FPS if too many people are on it-Limited "Bag Space" unless you spend money-Can be very boring without friends to play with over long periods of timeNEUTRALS:These are points that may be interesting to others and worth mentioning. I personally just love leveling Characters in games and not the biggest fan of these points, I may enjoy them once in awhile, but its not my reasons for playing the game and wouldnt care if they get taken out.-+Raids-+PvP

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												I've played since beta and I do admit i wish i had bought into the founder's pack then.  The game wasn't the greatest but Brevik and team did not give up and the game is worth what i have spent on it.  I bought a large amount of Gs which I have barely spent any.  I'm not a costume guy or feel the need to get every hero soon as they come out.  So the $100 or so I've spent which has kept me occupied for at least 6 months and prevented me from buying a new game has been worth it.  The actual review:  If you're into Diablo and the endless item grind that it is then this game is for you.  The amount of heroes will never end and make this game the most repetitive game ever played.  I do enjoy it as a game that i can pick up and play anytime and there is at least something new be it a hero i have yet to get to or actual content.Actual content added within the year:  1 Midtown madness an endless instance which isn't the greatest content.  2 x-defense wave like survival mode for 5 players.  Holo sims wave like survival mode for 1-2 players.  3 Omega & Synergy systems that equates to more grinding the same content (account leveling).  4 Enchanting a new crafter5 Asgard content (thor dark world content)6 Man ape one shot story (actual content)7 Muspelheim raid (actual content but hard to get in unless you're part of a large group)So as you can see as far as actual new content and new stuff to do its very limited.  Compared to releasing 1 hero a month (and now team ups) you can tell where their focus was and continues to be.  This game to me feels like it's still in beta since they still haven't completed the full review of the starting heroes.  But it's on the right track and the next year is/will be exciting with the release of villains and another one shot that's on the list for sure.

y 4, 2014
												Marvel Heroes is a ActionRPG type game by Gazillion and from the original creator of Diablo. Some of you might remember playing Marvel: Ultimate Alliance back on the PS2, this is very similar to those types of games except you’re playing with lots of other people and have a massive roster of heroes to choose from.There is a crafting element to Marvel Heroes where you can level up vendors and crafters to unlock new recipes and gear augmentations. There are a few things to do besides playing the story missions of the game such as the open public dungeon Mid-town Manhattan and specific challenge terminals with a boss at the end, you can also queue up for X-Defence which is a survive as many waves of enemies as you can solo or with a group, and the Fire vs Ice PVP arena. More content is arriving monthly with new story missions and challenge terminals and of course new heroes and new costumes.FREE TO PLAY:When you create an account over at https://marvelheroes.com/ and login to the game from Steam you will be able to select one free “starter hero” from a pre-set roster. Hawkeye, Scarlet Witch, Thing, Daredevil and Storm were the original starter heroes you could pick from at launch several months ago. I’ve heard from other people that Gazillion has changed this a little and that certain heroes have been added to the starter hero roster, namely Captain America. I can’t confirm this because I already have Cap in my main roster.Yes Marvel Heroes is free to play, you don’t need to pay for new heroes if you don’t want to… but you will be required to grind fairly hard if you want to unlock your desired hero. A special item called an Eternity Splinter can drop at random at any time during the game when you defeat an enemy, you will need to collect anywhere from 400-600 of these to unlock one hero of your choosing. Your best bet to play as the hero you want is to actually purchase him or her, the average single hero pack will run you around $20 US currency or less.. There are some benefits to doing this. -You unlock your favourite hero right away, no grinding for weeks to earn Eternity Splinters.-You get your heroes STASH tab, this is an extra inventory tab in your shared STASH locker. Stash tabs at the moment cannot be unlocked with Eternity Splinters.-You get an additional costume or two for your hero. Costumes at the moment cannot be unlocked with Eternity Splinters.PAY TO WIN: Yes and No. There is a cash shop in the game where you can buy new heroes, stash tabs, costumes and items such as temporary XP boosters or Retcon devices which reset you’re heroes skill points so you can re-allocate them. The only real advantage a paying player has over a non-paying player at the moment is the XP boosters so they can level up a lot faster and the ability to buy more stash tabs for inventory space. There are usually a fair amount of seasonal sales in the cash shop throughout the year.HEROES and VILLAINS:There is a large roster of heroes to choose and play as, like..Iron Man, Hulk, Ms. Marvel, Captain America, Black Widow, Thor, Cyclops, Wolverine, Jean Grey, Gambit, Emma Frost, Storm, Colossus, Deadpool, Cable, Spider-Man, Rocket Raccoon, Ghost Rider, Luke Cage, Punisher and many more. Including some upcoming heroes and villains that have been announced for a release in 2014 such as Magneto, Juggernaut and Venom.Each hero for the most part plays differently than the next and has many different skill trees to put points into as you level up. You can literally have two people playing as Thor with two very different skill tree builds leaving you with two very different play styles.The basic types of heroes are you standard melee and ranged heroes… and those who are a hybrid of both. Spider-Man is a great example because depending on how you spend his level up points you can build him as a pure melee or pure ranged hero.VERDICT:If you loved Marvel: Ultimate Alliance on the Playstation or are a comics fan and loved the Diablo series, then you will feel right at home here. Marvel Heroes continues to get better each month in terms of re-balancing and content being added, this game has come a long ways for a “Free to Play” game in one short year. It is almost criminal that this game is free to play because it is very fun and addicting, especially if you are willing to pony up the dough and purchase a few of your favourite heroes.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
27, 2014
												A definite re-review of the game's score is necessary. Being able to fling Squirrels at enemies and seeing them explode makes this game an automatic 8/10. Everything else added on top of that averages out to be about 20/10. A little unfair perhaps? Perhaps you don't judge squirrel flinging as astutely as needed. The game follows the Diablo format while adding plenty of reasons to actually spend money on it. You can, in theory and practice, play this game for free. So go ahead. Yet, when you want to join in on the squirel chunking antics, go ahead and drop a few dollars on a great experience. This game is executed better than the new Diablo, but still feels like the design team is missing out on a few things. The UI could use some work and finding your way around feels too chaotic considering their attempt at a flowing narrative. The story seems to follow one straight line, yet they seem to have multiple instances of HUBs and a confusing array of shops and needlessly difficult crafting options. With the amount of loot the enemies drop, you'd assume a better labeling system would allow you to sort and pick better. It doesn't. A simple Green or Red arrow would allow me to see if equipment was better or not. I understand that each bit is entirely unique in some cases, but mostly, the amount of judgements I have to make is a little tiring compared to other titles. Ignore Metascore and try this game. After you've "Hulk Slam'd" and "Squirrelpocalypse'd" a few times, then judge for yourself. I have enjoyed it so far.

content:
er 19, 2014
												Superheroes are a weird subject for an ARPG/MMO-lite type game since those tend to be so gear-focused but MH makes it work. The game isn't without its flaws. In transforming it from its previous, universally panned incarnation to the present one, the devs have developed about a billion and a half systems, thrown them at the wall, and seen what sticks. Some of them are pretty half-baked or make power creep an ugly inevitability. But there's enough genuinely awesome stuff going on that MH mostly succeeds despite itself. And with a zillion characters to play and counting, you're sure to find something that matches your play style.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
21, 2014
												After spending a few hours playing this game, I can say with confidence that it is probably the best F2P game I have played. To be fair, I don't typically play F2P or MMO games but within my limited experience, I can say that this happens to be one of the good ones. Gameplay is similar to Diablo series which is awesome. Graphics are good but nothing special.So far the Community has been pretty nice in my experience. The F2P aspect is what it is. At no point have I felt that I NEED to spend any of my real money in order to enjoy the game. Costumes and characters beyond the first one you pick will all cost real money. Alternately, you can find pick ups that can eventually use to get a new character, but it seems like it may take an eternity to do so. The bottom line is that I do recommend this game. If you are someone that cannot abide F2P in any form, then I suggest you save yourself some pain and play something else. Otherwise, I do believe there is fun to be had here. As of this writing, I have yet to spend any money at all and am having a great time. I do, however plan to purchase a costume for my character and think the time I've spent and the money I will spend will add up to good value.

content:
7, 2015
												MH2015 is an a-rpg of sorts. Don't expect your tipical mmo game here. It's a fun and quick game but not without its drawbacks.The pros are as follows:You can play as one of a sizable cast of characters. You get to choose a starter and a second one the next day. You can also earn the rest of the characters via a farming system.Each of those character has different skills making each one a potentially unique experience.The maps and enemies are quite fun to play. Things like a a goon saying "aww, just get me to the cops already" are quite amusing.The cons are:The game is very repetetive. By the time you play your second character you'll know it by heart. The game is limited to only a few maps. This is a shame because every one of these maps has many events and easter eggs which lead you to wanting even more.The game tries to solve this repetetiveness by every now and then changing the directions of the map, which is endlessly annoying.A lot of farming. If this annoys you, then this is not a game for you. Final verict.I had a lot of fun in my time with the game. Many heroes were enjoyable and played well, better than i've seen them before. However one thing that stuck with me was the lack of variety. The same old same old eventually meant that i played the game less and less.Do NOT play if farming or repetetiveness frustrates you.Do Play if you want to try playing a marver character in an action game, this is where the game shines.Make SURE to use the funds for the free hero unlock you get on the second day to unlock your Favourite hero, it helps.

content:
er 13, 2013
												It's a grindy F2P Diablo2 clone with some modernization updates as well some F2P trappings.-Get free second class citizen/hero at start: CHECK!-Overpriced heroes/ARPG classes: CHECK! ($6-$14 approx.)-Grindy: CHECK!-Way-overpriced costumes: CHECK!!!-Odd earned-in-game currency: CHECK! (1 Eternity Splinters drops every 4-6 minutes on average, 200/400/600 buy you a hero).This game sucked sweaty, ♥♥♥♥-slathered sloth shaft back in June/July when it was released.  In a desperate attempt to save their careers, Gazillion has taken the awkward, and hopefully forced by a higher IP owning hand, release game and made the game not vivaciously thumb a dirty brown eye like all reviews make it sound like it does.  Seriously, the game has had immense amounts of post-mortem content and polish that might not get much visibility unless people actually play it and feel sorry for Gazillion enough to hand them money.Bias: I paid $20 during the beta, regretted it until November when the game stopped being bad.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2013
												This is officially my new sick addiction lol. The game had a rough start with its bizarre F2P model but just about everything has been reworked since then. No longer do you have to pray for a random hero to drop as loot or get the 2 more lame starter heroes from beating the story. With the implementation of Eternity Splinters and Cube Shards you can earn for FREE new Heroes and alternative costumes. You can have hours upon hours (I'm almost to 100 hrs lol) of fun playing this game without ever spending a single cent. I recently did buy $20 bucks of in game currency to buy a STASH box and mostly just to support the Devs that made this fantastic game. Its rich in the lore of Marvel and the X-Men. There are currently 29 playable heroes with each one playing entirely fresh and different from the last one you scrambled through the game with. In 2014 we are getting an additional 12 characters with some being infamous playable Villans such as Venom, Magneto and Juggernaut. Nightcrawler is the next character due out and Ghostrider just became playable so in my honest opinion this is the best time to try this game out or give it another shot if you were unhappy with the model when it was first released. Oh and did I mention Deadpool has an unmasked attire, Hulk can SMASH in a Santa Hat, and Emma Frost can charm enemies into fighting along side her? I'll leave it at that :D

												Let's be clear about this, when Marvel Heroes launched, it was an unfinished mess. Leveling was grueling, many characters were simply not tuned to be at all effective and the loot was pretty bland. Somehow though, I still put 50 hours into it because there was something there.Six months on, and the game is practically unrecognisable. New areas, systems, characters, pvp, loot types and dungeons have been added. All characters have recently been rebalanced and seem fun to play. For players who like to play a single character there is an interesting prestige system which allows multiple playthroughs on one character and for altoholics like me, there is a hero synergy system which adds decent benfits depending on which characters you have leveled.Combine all of this with one of the most responsive dev teams I have ever seen in the MMO space and an extremely friendly community and you have a really excellent game. Highly recommended.

content:
6, 2016
												The Marvel Universe has a character for everyone to enjoy, and you can pick from a lot of them from here, and the list is growing still.  The gameplay is fun and satisfying, I don't notice much of a grind just loving running around smashing AIM goons' faces in with elbow drops from She Hulk or an uppercut from Ant Man, or just eating them as Venom.  I actually have had more positive interactions with social chats than any other game I have seen, but of course, chats can get toxic as with anything else, be ready for those small moments.  Game is pretty simple, but still has some things to delve into.  You can choose to grind for THE BEST gear, but honestly, you don't need to.  Game is free to play fair, I got two heroes I really liked for free, and played them a lot, but then when I felt like I loved the game, I payed for some inventory and a few more heroes I really wanted. If you like MARVEL this game is great!  If you want to get into MARVEL this is also great!  If you want a time killer with some fun and simple combat Diablo style, also great!If you somehow can only see any game with loot as a farm fest, then no, but then you wouldn't even look at a game like this, let alone a review, right?

15, 2014
												Overall this is a really good game.  They have weekly patches that contain events and fixes. New content is added pretty quick compaired to other games.  Crazy amount of heroes to choose from if you pay for them, they can also be aquired in game with currency that drops but it takes 200 - 600 eternity splinters to get (which 1 drops about every 6 minutes). Hero packs are well priced for what items you get with them.  Muptiple costumes for each hero, which is really cool (They can drop but is very rare. Also can be purchased).  This is an ARPG/MMO (Setup similar to Diablo).  The first couple heroes you level will be a bit of a grind, but you really learn how to play the game in that time frame.  I would recommend getting your Crafter and Enchanter leveled up for upgrades as you level. Check this game out if you like ARPG games or MMO style games.  Pick a starter hero for free and try it on!

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												PROS:-A huge and ever expanding roster of your favorite Marvel heroes-All heroes can be obtain through playing the game-Story mode is a good length and fun to play -Endgame has improved tremendously since launch-Constant updates monthly -New PvP mode-Fun combat-Free-to-PlayCONS:-Game needs solo/group dungeons outside of reusing story mode instances-No hardcore mode-No ladder resetsSCORE: 8THOUGHTS:Let's get right to it. When the game originally launched back in June of this year the reception wasn't great; okay it was bad. The game gave a bad first impression to new players that didn't participated in the beta. Marvel Heroes has a lot of heroes to choose from (27 heroes and counting) and at launch the only way to obtain more heroes outside of rare drops (which were pretty damn rare) were to buy them with real money. Okay, that doesn't sound to bad right? Wrong. The pricing for the heroes were outrageous at the time, costing upwards of $20+ for some of the premium heroes like Iron Man and Spiderman. This left a bad taste in a lot of peoples' mouths. But now, this has all changed. Gazillion Entertainment has listen to their community and brought prices down to much more reasonable levels. Top tier heroes will cost about $9 to buy, much better than $20+ dollars back then. There are packs that may cost more but that's up to the individual on if it's worth it to buy. But the best news was how Gazillion added an ingame currency called, "Eternity Splinters" that you can farm and use to purchase the hero that you want, without paying a dime. This was a welcome and needed change. Now players can get every hero in the game just by playing the game!Some of the other things that Marvel Heroes had a bad rap about was the combat was boring and there was nothing to do once you beat the game. Well, Gazillion has been busy reworking heroes and changing visuals and making combat much more exciting this time around. I remember playing Iron Man on launch day and thought to myself that he was kind of weak and dare I say it..boring. But when I came back for update 2.0, Iron Man felt like, well, Iron Man and he was so much more fun to play. The endgame was lacking as well like I mentioned before and once you beat the game you were either running the same terminals over and over to grind to max level or you were leveling an alt. Gazillion has added much more things to do this time around. Along with your daily terminal runs you can also replay the game in two other difficulties, Heroic and Superheroic. Or you can farm items and grind levels on huge maps like Midtown Manhattan with other players or play a survival style game in X-Defense where you protect students from the Xavier School from an invasion. Also, a new addition to the game is PvP called, "Fire & Ice", which is still in beta where it's a 5 vs 5 where you protect your giants and attack other players and their giants onto destroying their base to win the match. On top of that, Marvel Heroes is now starting to add more chapters to the game, starting with Chapter 9 in Asgard. In the coming months there will be more additions to Asgard as it expands, for now, we have a small taste of what's to come.Gazillion is doing a tremendous job listening to their players and making changes as quickly as possible to ensure quality. As well, as giving us new content and updates every month. If you played the game when it first came out or are discouraged about its low Metacritic scores, don't be, the game has improved leaps and bounds since then. Gazillion has a determination to make Marvel Heroes the best ARPG ever, you can be sure that greater things lies in store for us in the near future and the best part is that's all free! Give this game a shot (or another shot) and you won't be disappointed.

content:
28, 2014
												I tried Marvel Heroes when it first launched and thought it was freemium, pay-to-win garbage. I'd heard it had greatly improved over the last 5-6 months and was much better, so I decided to give it another shot. I'm glad I did.It's a really fun ARPG with frequent content updates, a sane pay model (all purchasable content is either completely cosmetic [costumes, pets] or also available through playing/grinding), regular events (with bonus XP/loot), and a decent loot/crafting system. Although you're playing on servers with other people and while there is support for groups (and talk of raid content coming in a future update), it also seems to be one of the most solo-friendly ARPGs of recent years -- nice for when you're feeling antisocial and just want to grind some loot. Marvel Heroes can be a little rough around the edges in spots but overall it's a really enjoyable game, regardless of how much or how little money you spend on it.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												I play using -nosteam so hours are not accurate. I like this game and play it a ton but it definitely has some flaws as an ARPG. It is held aloft by clever use of the Marvel franchise.ProsGameplay Free to play.Wide array of Marvel characters to choose from, new release monthly. Different types of game modes, up to and including MMO style raids, with varying levels of "difficulty" and time commitment.Flavor! Popular classic and new costumes, variant costumes, ENHANCED costumes that do things like gender swap, character swap, power color swap, VA swap. Many Team-ups that can tag along with you. A few cool visual effects you can add to your costume. MMO style build trees with unlimited resets allows some variety in power sets. Plus Omega Point system allowing further stat customization with tons of choices.Cybernetic pets add a small extra possibility for stat customization along with the ability to "vacuum" (eat) loot off the ground plus the actual pet following you around when summoned.Design shift towards for easy travel with vehicles, fast running, flying, teleporting at low or no resource cost.Play solo or in a group.GraphicsAt max settings there is a nice colorful style taking the middle of the road between gritty realism and cartoony. The dynamic lighting and shadows are quite nice and the motion blur effect is not overdone. With full effects on this game looks absolutely bonkers. You actually really need to turn them down or you can't even see your own character!Constantly improving character and costumes design. Many older characters are starting to get reworked looks to be of much higher quality than release.AudioBeing an official Marvel approved franchise they have some great known VAs and realistic lines for fully voiced heroes, Team-ups, and villains.Indicators for certain rare drops.Pricing and Misc.You start out with one free hero and by earning in-game currency you can buy any hero or Team-up of your choice without $. Through log-in rewards  you are given enough currency to buy a medium priced hero or Team-up and then other things like bonus exp, power tree resets, and even some special pet and Team-up items after 100+ days.There are multiple special events that run almost constantly with special rewards and/or server side boosts.ConsGameplayAs with any ARPG, grinding is the name of the game. You can buy $ boosts but the drop rate of most things you want is so low you won't feel  an appreciable difference until you have 4 or more $ boosts going."Difficult" another trap of the ARPG this is largely based on your gear and Omega points level, not skill. I would say MH falls into artificial difficulty harder than any other MMO and ARPG games I have played. Especially the largely disappointing "boss" fights that exist outside of raids that have less to do with the boss and more to do with not standing in stuff on the ground.Balance with 40+ heroes on the roster is a tough job and the variance between top and bottom is quite extreme in both dummy TTKs, live DPS efficiency, and especially TTL. Newer heroes and recently updated heroes are largely better off in all departments. Some old characters excluded from current raid content entirely.Lots of multi-tree heroes only have one build that is considered viable and this is not a problem with power design but simple numbers tuning.Power sets and especially buff durations and debuff durations are becoming completely normalized and homogenized over time. This makes future balance easier but it also makes heroes feel less unique from each other.Some of the game modes have such a lack of reward and tuning that they are abandoned at the moment by the players AND the devs until they can be modified and improved. (X-DEF, Holo-SIM)The stylistic choice of real world size villains is understandable but with some villains and heroes even being the same, and the huge amount of spell effects flying around, tracking combat (mainly where the boss is facing so as not to stand in front of it) can be very difficult.Crafting is outdated and tedious. One of the remnants of release MH from before the 2015 rebranding that is simply too low on the priority totem poll to be adjusted. One of the main crafting ingredients, Runes, have too many rare drop rates for useful Runes and too many completely useless Runes which is both pointless and confusing for new players.Omega system is bloat, most options are useless and it's new player unfriendly. It also encourages EXP farming over loot farming if you want to cap points.GraphicsEverything can be turned off but I'm not sure there is actually much gains for doing so. When I had an older CPU I could play perfectly on the TEST Center but had extreme lag on live, so poor server performance can exacerbate CPU usage of MMO type games which are already notorious for being CPU heavy.AudioAccents tend to be questionable at best and quite inconsistent. The same VA used for multiple characters in some situations and unfortunately it's obvious.A few characters have a disconnect between the mix of eras their look and voice and lines were pulled from. EX: Rogues default look is modern but her voice sounds very young and rebellious and her lines are like OG completely scared of her powers and unable to control them, yet her power set has no instability, She steals and uses whatever she wants whenever she wants.Some characters have a lot more lines than others.Low pool of lines for villains.Pricing and Misc.Expensive. A hero, Team-up , costume is ~$10 per. Boosts ~$1 per hour per. Playing just one hero is not something most people do because you run out of content variety very quickly.Costumes and bank space are $ only.No lowering the price of old content. That means that this old style release costume[i.ytimg.com]  is the same price as this new style 2015 costume[glasscannon.ru]. Team-ups were made the same price as playable heroes because they took the same work, and I respect that in part, it just doesn't make sense from a consumer stand-point for those two things to be the same price.The actual gameplay time involved in getting even one hero or Team-up from free currency is significant.DevelopmentBalance, improvement of older AI, outdated modes, and graphics, restructuring of outdated systems, all take a backseat to new content and the all-important Release Schedule.Hero balance comes in monthly single characters reviews. That means unbalanced heroes remain untouched for over 6 months at a time. But "OP" builds get nerfed within a week, and often into oblivion.They clearly had and have a huge vision for the scope, but it comes more and more at the expense of current gameplay. Almost everything from the original release needs to be updated or reworked and this happens much much more slowly than new content which comes with its own issues and bugs.So many bugs reported on TC and purposefully released to live, to be fixed at a later patch date. It seems that Marvel approval interferes occassionally and Gaz is forced to take the blame for it. Some of the devs can talk and act unprofessionally when interacting on social media, making personal and petty insults to customers and taking criticism, while understandably personally, poorly.

content:
10, 2016
												Mahval Heroes is a Diablo style rpg that you play as various heroes/anti-heroes from the Marval universe. The game underwent a massive rebuild because the old game was boring, and you didnt get to play who you wanted to. As of now you can play all heroes up to Lv 10 and unlock anyone from the start.Now game play wise I find it to be a very relaxing pick up and play type game, no stressful things like dps gates/hours of required grind. There is alot of variety in the people you can play like Venom who can be a hybrid ranged/melee who is all about regen to Storm who is a walking AoE (Area of Effect) with well storms. Now some heroes are still not up to date to the new current standard of fun but they are being worked on. The cash shop is fairly standard like League of Legends $10 more or less for heroes and costumes (with exeption of ENHANCED that change model voice lines and ability flavor). Small boost comsumables etc.Now the game isnt for everyone if you dont like dungeon crawlers for loot this it not for you. If you are concerned about the END GAME there are raids and cosmic trials/danger room that ups the difficulty, two raids currently in game more on the way. If want to feel powerfull kill tons of goons and get loot this may be the game for youTLDRPros - Most heroes feel strongJust about everything can be earned in gameLarge variety in playable classesDecent storyFor Marval fans lots of fan service between costumes and character interactionsCons - Storage Space is a large problem free players dont get that much (This is they only thing they dont give away in spades)Just starting out everything can be a bit slowIf you have bad RNG it can take a while to get what you want

content:
, 2015
												Well, I felt the need to clarify some things as recent reviews have been negative, and there is NO good reason for this.The Draws:A must for Marvel comic fans, as this is very true to the source material, while still including enough of the Marvel Cinematic Universe references to delight the fans of only the movies.The art and banter in this game are fantastic. This game is chock full of flavorful tidbits that delight in every sense.The customization for builds is nearly limitless and the same hero can be in a group with two different builds and feel like two totally different heroes.The endgame is MASSIVE. There are a lot of things to do once at max level, and the game even has options to rerun the level up process for your favorites, with some cool benefits for those who choose to do so.Solid gameplay and controls. This game feels very polished and complete. Brevik's team knows their stuff.The game is genuinely and oftentimes GLORIOUSLY fun.This is how Free-to-Play SHOULD be done. You have access to most things without ever LOOKING at a store to spend real money. If you are willing to put in the time and effort, you can get access to whatever your heart desires (for the most part).The Turn-offs:Lack of fresh content. Though there is a full storyline mode, it feels short (which the game has on 3 difficulty modes, so you run it 3 times to totally complete the story on a character). The One-Shots and Raids have their own storylines, but they are mostly setups to boss fights, and not a ton of character progression. The new Ultron game mode also has a story, but it isn't anything to be impressed about.Depending on who your favorite character is, you may be completely useless in a raid setting, being forced to level up a raid-appropriate character to run on if you wish to participate in raids.Repetition. This game has it. In spades. This game has it. In spades. Repetition.Summary:This game is worth playing through and is a very solid MMO that is fun. There is stuff constantly being added to the game and plenty of events in which to participate. So Assemble your team and get to Smashing.Excelsior!(P.S. Plenty of cameos. Including a few by his royal Generalissimo, Stan The Man.)

												I recommend this game to people that are in to Marvel and MMO style games. The game is well designed and has a mixture of both action and humor. You do not have to invest a lot of money in this game like you do with most games in this style (such as Final Fantasy and World of Warcraft).It is a great game to play with friends, but you rarely have the ability to make friends on here. Most people keep to themselves and do not bother others. There is so much to do allowing there to be endless fun. Now that all that is said, I will now address the small downsides to the game. The graphics have a lot of stress on a computer. I recommend lowering the settings. If you are not sure exactly what to lower, you just need to hover your cursor on the text and the game will tell you what the option does and if lowering it would help.The game is rather confusing at first. The 'tutorial' at the beginning should explain more than it already does. It only explains how to move, attack, and things like that.The game can get rather boring without friends. There is a lot of options to do, but most are very much alike. Over all, this game is very worth getting. I highly recommend it.

content:
2, 2016
												Upon the release of the new Travelling update, and another dozen or so hours of the game under my belt, I decided to revisit my review.If you're a comic book lore-lord, there's probably plenty of fanservice and fun bits to sink your teeth into. Plenty of opportunity to play as heroes or villains that aren't often playable in games.For someone that doesn't have any sort of emotional investment in Marvel though, it's....pretty average. The core gameplay loop is more entertaining than what Diablo 3 is doing these days, since there's a fair amount of variety in what you can do for end-game progression. Rather than provide you an endless progression ladder in the form of Greater Rifts as in Diablo 3, Marvel Heroes offers multiple acceptable paths for leveling, and several systems to interact with to gather gear, some of which is harder than others. The power curve is a little smoother - Diablo 3 has you feeling useless until you collect set items, at which point you power increases exponentially, whereas Marvel Heroes is content to let you feel strong right away, with some higher difficulty content gated off until you've reached certain gear thresholds that vary from character to character. Since we've already gone into the diablo comparison - Blizzard put a lot more love into their spell effects and making sure everything has a nice, meaty feeling of impact. Spell effects and the way your abilities interact with the enemies can leave you feeling impotent at times, even if some of the spells or skills have large or flashy graphics associated with them. In general, the aesthetics are lacking a certain level of polish. Characters in Diablo can generally succeed without someone 'tanking' the hits, since if you're not powerful enough to manage without something distracting the enemy, you're playing on the wrong difficulty anyway. Marvel Heroes has a 'team-up' system that lets you call-in a sidekick of sorts, which serve different utility purposes - some may tank for you, using their abilities to quickly jump into the fight and stun or slow foes, giving you time to kill them or control them yourself before they've leapt into your face. Characters that don't need a tank or can summon one as one of their innate abilities are free to take a team-up that can debuff the enemies, or simply add to their DPS. I'd say it's a nice middle-ground between the mercenary system present in Diablo 2 and 3, as you have many viable options that can fit a variety of roles depending upon your needs.The travel system has been dramatically improved. Before this most recent patch, you had to spend points in your travel power, and it started off with a base speed of 500, barely faster than your default running speed. Now you are automatically granted a travel power at level 10, and you can assign it a dedicated button independent of your hotbars. Better yet, it doesn't take away any of your skill points, and now everyone has a power granting them a movement speed of 650, which feels great. Heroes that can teleport still have a movement advantage, but with this travel update, the game still feels plenty playable and satisfactory, even if you can only run around on foot.The game follows the korean MMO model of inventory management. That is to say, they give you a pretty small inventory and a pitiful stash size to work with, and then procede to shower you with more loot than you know what to do with. There are systems in place to help alleviate this, such as automatically trashing items below certain quality thresholds, and a pet system that requires you to feed them large volumes of drops in order to make them more effective at what they do for you, but this is a band-aid at best. Finding items doesn't feel cool, because there's so many stats, variables, and levers that each gearslot can be pulling, that comparing a new drop to what you're wearing feels tedious. Even after a few dozen hours of play, the best solution I've found is to ignore anything that's not at least "cosmic", and generally only spend time evaluating new items if there's a large level gap in what i'm wearing vs what just dropped, or if it's unique and has stat bonuses or perks specific to the character i'm playing as.Costumes are pretty expensive, too. They're asking roughly $10 for a single costume wearable by one hero, which is out of the impulse buy range for most people, myself included. You are also only allowed one free hero per account. To be fair to them, they do have a form of in-game currency that can be used to buy new heroes, and the drops feel slightly generous - between what you pick up in the course of regular play, and what you're awarded for doing side-quests as you work through the main story, you can expect that you'll be able to buy one new hero just about every time you level a character from 1-60, assuming you do so using the campaign. It's worth mentioning that the side quests are pretty grindy and depend upon random spawns and timed events to complete, which can be tedious to wait for and complete. I suspect that this is by design, giving you a way to measure whether it's worth your time to get this secondary source of splinter income, or just drop some cash on heroes.For what it's worth, there's daily login rewards too, and on your 7th day of logging in, you get a large sum that's enough to buy 1 or 2 heroes. If there's anything in this game that encourages you to keep going, it's the drop system they've implemented so you can unlock more heroes. On every 10th and 30th day thereafter, you get a login bonus of 10 shards too, which really starts to add up.As a paid title, I'd be wary of recommending it. But it's free to play, and has a pretty ethical (albeit expensive) business model that never sells you in-game power. If you like the Marvel universe or don't consider yourself above playing an average callback to games like Diablo, Torchlight, and Marvel: Ultimate Alliance, it couldn't hurt to install this and give it a shot.

content:
, 2016
												I have seen negative reviews of this game when it first released.One night I was bored, and decided to dig in to Marvel Heroes.I am glad I did, and even though it is years later. That may be the best thing. Now they have a preview option for the characters before perming your choice. I had lag in one instance, however upon going to another it was cured within the same game. The beatem up linear style is usually something I am against. But due to the MMO style fan base where you can see others, and have them help you along your journey makes it even more entertaining allowing it to go above passable.The loot system to me is a bit complex, but I played MMO's when Warcraft was first releasing so I may be out of my league until I get more up to snuff which I am sure will happen easily with time. That isn't a fault on the system, just me failing to easily become familier with it in a quick amount of time.The end game seems decent enough, I have yet to achieve it due to the level cap and how long it takes to reach it with a single character. However I hear very good things, and if that isn't your flavor you can always swap characters trying a new one out.One downside as with most Free to Play titles, is after you choose your character. You only get one character, that you can fully level up. With out putting in some good amount of time, or money you will be stuck to this character. So make sure you choose wisely and test each one to ensure your good experience.Path of Exile with Marvel. That is what it feels like to me, maybe even a bit simplified which isn't a bad thing.Best game I have seen Free To Play wise, and with a controller it is a fun way to spend some hours messing around at the very least. I would give this game a try even for casual beat em up fans, that have some what of a back ground in being a Marvel fan. Because the Marvel cosmetic really keeps the game fresh to another extent. At least it does for me.

												For free or low-spending players, this game is great to experience, but might not be one you stay with. The heros are pricey for anyone who feels the desire to collect, BUT you can play with ANY and ALL heros up until they are level 10, and to progress further you either buy them or use points you very slowly collect in the world.It's like Marvel Ultimate Alliance, except that each hero has far more depth and diversity within their skill trees, so like a mix between that and Diablo 2.Happily, your first fully unlocked hero can be ANYONE. Don't just consult any simple list of "reccommended" starter heros, you can go my route and unlock Rogue, who can steal powers from ANY other character in the game, giving you a first character that is amazingly diverse. Then I had enough points to unlock Emma Frost for free, and she can mind control any minion or monster in the game to be her persistant pet/bodyguard.  :))))I LOVE this game.

												I have played this game far too much since it's release, and it's come a long way since then! Six months ago I would've not recommended this game and not given it a second thought. I'm really glad I decided to pick it up again recently, all of the new additions to the game have made it much more fun and a bit addicting. I'm often hesitant about free to play games of this style as I have found they usually tend to have a large amount of important content that needs to be bought to really play the entire game. While there may be a few convenience issues for non-paying players (primarily in STASH space) the payment model is actually quite fair, with nearly everything in the game available through in-game currencies, including every hero and team-up hero. If you like the Marvel universe, or ARPGs in general you should definitely give it a shot.

content:
, 2016
Product received for free
												I've been playing this game off and on since Beta, and it's one that I've grown to be very happy with. Marvel Heroes 2016 is not the Marvel Heroes that was released straight out of Beta. When I first played it I wasn't sure if I really liked it. I would have given it mediocre at best. But as it stands today with the amount of content it offers, this is quite possibly the best Free-to-Play game on the market - especially if you're an ARPG fan as I am.Yes, I said Free-to-Play and NOT Pay-to-win. Just about everything (if not all) in Marvel Heroes is attainable in some form or another without needing spend a single dime. But I do admit it can be time consuming, and if you're hoping to get a specific costume for free then pray to RNGesus. I put money into the game because it's a game that I love and believe deserves it. The only thing I still don't agree with are the costume prices, but at least they have no bearing on gameplay or how well you perform. I've played just about all the current ARPG games out now and Marvel Heroes is still my favourite. It offers a cast of characters that I love, gameplay that is really addicting and fun, and varied modes that keeps it refreshing. At some point I'm sure I'll wander off to play something else, but I know I'll eventually be back for more.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
17, 2016
												When Marvel Heroes first came out in 2013, I didn't really think much of it.  The P2W aspects were completely in your face, the grind was horrendous, it paled in comparison to Path of Exile and even Diablo 3, and it just wasn't fun.Three years later...dear god.  I've never seen a game go from a 50 to a 100 in such a way.  It is very clear that Gazillion has immense passion for this game, and it shows.  So many things have improved, and now Marvel heroes is easily one of my favorite ARPGs ever.Pros:- Over 50 iconic Marvel characters, each brought to life by excellent VA and superb writing.- While several characters are similar to each other, they're all unique in their own way just enough to make each new character a new experience.- TRULY free to play. Back in 2013, getting new heroes without shelling out real money was a pipe dream at BEST. You could only get them by finding Hero Tokens that had a .01% chance of dropping.  Now, however, every Hero and Team Up can be purchased with Eternity Splinters, which generally drop from every 10th enemy or so.  The prices are reasonable, and the payoff is well worth it.  But as for real money, this is pretty much the ONLY F2P game I have no problem spending money on, because I honestly believe the devs DESERVE it for all the hard work they've put into it.- Extremely flexible gameplay. Most of the "big" ARPGs tend to be gated by having endgames that completely decimate you if you didn't build your character's skills and/or stats in an EXACT way.  Marvel Heroes though?  You can do whatever and you won't get penalized!  Want to make Doctor Doom or Ultron pure ranged DPS and not a summoner?  Go ahead!  Want to make Cyclops melee only?  No problem!  The list goes on, and the possibilities are near endless.- Extremely active dev team and community: Like I said, Gazillion clearly has passion for this game.  Every other week, a new event goes live that grants you unique content, such as items, costumes and even Team Ups.  Their 3rd anniversy this past June was, in my opinion, one of the best MMO events I've ever taken part in.- The new level scaling system.  Not only does it make leveling much less stressful, but it also keeps everything at a consistent challenge level.  No more breezing through each Hero's "Vs Doctor Doom" achievement for you.  Now you have to WORK to beat him before the three minute mark!Cons:- Maybe this is just me, but ever since the Avengers Tower revamp, several areas tend to be very lag heavy.  Or maybe this one's just my internet connection.- March to Axis is WAY too hard!  If you ever read this, Gaz, please consider toning down the health for the HYDRA Hulkbusters.  Or at the very least, get rid of the massive dps AoE they use when at half health!- Still no Ultron achievement for the steam version.  Hopefully it will be added when Angela goes live.Overall verdict: 9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												This is possible the best game out there right now, ergo that's why loads of people play it. It's short told a Diablo-game the way Diablo 3 should have been. It's Diablo 3: Marvel Universe Edition. The CEO of Gazillion was the guy that worked on both Diablo 1 and Diablo 2.It had a rough start, as all MMOs do. And Gazillion has done so many great things since launch. Improved it extremely much.It's a F2P game in which you choose from 9 heroes(previously 5) at the start, then you run through the game in story mode, and you get to about level 22-24. Then you can either run the story two more times in order to get to max level, which is 60. Or you can start doing PvP at around level 20(but it's still in in beta), it has this MOBA-style map and combat, and more to come. You can start doing terminal, which is essensial dungeons which you recognize from the game, when you ran through it in story mode. Two types of terminals are currently in the game, green and red. Red being the harder version of the terminal.While you play you will have several drops that are mighty important. Eternity Splinters is the in-game currency in which you can buy and unlock more heroes, and you can buy gear and respec potions for it. I'm told you should get at least 1 ES within 8 minutes, and you have more ways to improve this. Other drops that are important is relics, which drops after you get level 25. These stack to about 1000 and will increase your characters stats by alot and the type of your choice - even when you're not playing that spesific character you can still "boost" the stats of the character.After level 25 you will also be granted legendary quests, which drops alot of experience, money and most importantly Odin marks. Marks can be traded in for legendary items, items that level up with you, and get extremely good at rank 5(5 levels).All the heroes play differently, and they are working to get several build options for each that is viable. It's so fun to be a part of this game, and Gazillion really listens to the community. And has some really cool heroes coming(Ghost Rider, Nightcrawler, Beast, X-23++), and the next chapter of the Asgard patch will deliver loads of things, raid is one of them.Several friends of mine play, and some are quite surprised and angry with themselfs that they didn't get into this game earlier. I'm throwing all my money into this, because I do support a good game, and wouldn't want to stop the fun factor of it, supporting and funding the game all I can, but you don't really have to!

content:
er 10, 2016
												I only recommend this game because it is free, as initially it was a lot of fun and it is very addictive, but the replay value just wasn't there for me and the in game items are laughably overpriced (Unlock Ultron + his skin from the movie = £15, £6 for one skin). The characteristations of the heroes are excellent, they are all represented very well in terms of their powers and how they use them for example as Spiderman you will be swinging and flipping everywhere at warp speed, as Hulk you will be plowing through everything, as Ultron you will be spawning waves of drones to fight for you etc and as I said initially this is great fun. My main issue with this Diablo style gameplay is that there is simply no skill whatsoever involved, endless waves of enemies come at you and you simply demolish them one after another, the only enemies that even require you to dodge their attacks are 2 or 3 of the "boss" villains, the rest of the game you can just stand directly in the middle of a full screen of enemies clicking the left mouse button and if your health starts to drop just press ASDFGH and you will have killed every enemy on screen and regenerated all your health (don't believe me? give it a try!)Also it's not an mmorpg, it's basically a single player game with a chat box. Nobody does anything together (you don't need to) and there is no interaction between players save the global chat.It's fun as a Marvel roleplay experience to a certain extent, but after you have reached level 60 and completed the story there isn't anything else to do unless you like grinding. If you are confused because this sounds like a negative review, it is. The only reason I recommend the game because it's fun for the first few hours and it's free so if your connection is quick enough that you can stomach the 20gig download for a few hours of running around as Captain America then give it a try!

content:
ber 22, 2014
												With a huge roster of Marvel superheroes - and after some serious game-improving patches over the last year - this is a Diablo-like fans of the genre wouldn’t want to miss. You pick from a decent handful of starter heroes, like Punisher, Black Widow, Captain America, Colossus or Storm, then go about fighting through a nine-chapter campaign either by yourself or with friends. If you’ve ever played Diablo, Torchlight or other games in the genre, this is exactly like that except a bit more bombastic. Overpowered doesn’t even begin to describe how it all feels, but it fits the topic well.As you play, an in-game currency drops with regularity which can be used to unlock additional heroes. Or, if you’re impatient, you can buy more heroes with real money. But I’d recommend just saving up the in-game currency for the hero you want, it doesn’t take that long. Once you finish the campaign, you can replay it on increasing difficulty levels for better drops, or hit up a variety of end-game content types like horde-style holo missions. There’s even high-level raids, but those require max-level characters and a firm understanding of how to play.Before the “2015” patch, I was hesitant to recommend Marvel Heroes to anyone. But to Gazillion’s credit, they’ve overhauled the game dramatically, and now it’s a must-play in my book.

content:
, 2014
												TLDR: Marvel Heroes is an excellent ARPG, and is well worth the download.The Good:-Free to play, and not Pay to Win. You can earn everything in game without cash. Including costumes (however, costumes are extremely time prohibitive to earn, and random besides.)-Large roster of playable characters, with a new character coming out every month.-Older characters don't get forgotten, every month an older character also recieves a review pass, ensuring that they're keeping up with the new guys.-Tons of stuff to do, including pvp, terminal missions, neverending zones with progressive difficulty ramp, story mode, one-shot story lines (side stories not related to the main storyline), numerous items to farm, several collectable currencies, crafting, enchanting, etc.-Characters often have multiple builds that work efficiently.-"Team Up" sidekick characters with multiple skill paths add variety.-Constant updates, with significant progress, and a willingness to listen to the playerbase.The Bad-Story mode gets repetitive, however several story quests give permanent bonuses to your character, forcing you to complete them if you want to max everything out.-The fortune card system is just aweful, and needs to be rethought.-PVP is still in 'beta' and needs a lot of polish.-The sheer number of Iron Man costumes taking up my stash space.-Some costumes are just re-colored versions of the original.The Fugly-It can get repetitive. Of course, it Is an ARPG, where repetitive is the name of the game....-Grouping and guilds need more content, which is starting to be adressed with the release of raids.-Pvp.-Stash space is bought with real money only, making it the only thing not attainable through in game means.In conclusion, I think Marvel Heroes is the perfect backup game, the game you play when you want to take a break from The Elder Scrolls Online, or League of Legends, or whatever it is that floats your boat. The way it's built, and the rate at which it's being actively developed, even if there's something you hate, if you come back a month or two later, odds are if it isn't fixed, it's at least different. I've been playing since closed beta, and have gone through spurts where MH is my main game, and spurts where I'm addicted to other games, and go back to MH when I get bored. It's kinda like your wife, really. When you get tired of your hot mistress, you can count on her being there, waiting for you at home, with your dinner ready for you.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
10, 2014
												This game is an innovator. Like anchovies and cherry Jell-O, Marvel Heroes has dared to combine two ingredients that were conventionally kept separate: MMOs and ARPGs (aka Diablo-style games). Any challenge, story, or sense of skillful execution that previously existed in the ARPG genre has been thoughtfully removed from the game, so that the player may enjoy a more pure experience of applying their mouse skills onto a screen that is marvelously flashing. Nostalgia seekers rejoice! The talent trees in Marvel Heroes have rolled back the clocks on modern MMO talents that focus on important decisions and noticeable changes to gameplay. Instead they embrace the charm and whimsy of early-era talent trees that provide incremental damage increases and minor improvements to existing abilities. Don't worry about needing an abacus to figure out the talent trees though, it's literally almost impossible to make a decision of any sort as you fill in the points.The challenging and exciting dungeon crawl experience that we all remember from the peak of the MMO era lives on Marvel Heroes. The challenge of coordinating carefully and skillfully with your team mates to overcome incredible odds has been seamlessly replaced with the challenge of racing to keep up with your team as you all swing, slide, teleport, and sprint for the center of the next room. And you'd best master your simple movement ability quickly! You want to get to the next room while enemeis are still standing so you can begin pressing your strongest AOE attack! It makes colors!While the excitement of hard-earned triumph is only a faint memory, the pulce-pounding thrill we felt as we peeked into a slain monster's treasure horde has been generously shmeared across the entire experience so that it never violently peaks like that again. This leads to a very mellow, constant influx of unexciting rewards. Ideal for today's anxiety-prone gamers.Take a step away from the pressure of needing to learn complex "mechanics" in your game. I don't even know what a carburetor is. Something in bread that makes you fat? Whatever, leave the science to the "hardcore" gamers. Sit back, prop up your mouse hand, and take a stroll with a reasonable approximation of some of your not-quite-favorite "super" "heroes".

content:
, 2014
												This game, is one of my favourite F2P games I have played for a long long time. Besides Warframe, I enjoy this game HIGHLY, because of this lush enjoyment and it's variety. As a fan of Marvel and Comics in General, I love seeing the references to Marvel's Lore and all sorts of Marvel things, which makes this game the more entertaining.This game is said to be similar to Diablo III, which I haven't played so I cannot comment. Though I have played for only a short few hours (In game terms, it would be short), I have so far had fun with the Hero I had started to play with, as well as the one who I am currently levelling along side with my Mid 30's Gambit char (I got Gambit, Punisher (Defunct) and Psylocke). That being said, it can be quite a bore just levelling, but then again, this is minor due to the variety this game gives.A few cons for me would be the Eternity Splinters, the alternative to the Pay To Win route in this game. I admit, I paid for Gambit and Psylocke because both of these characters was a major want for me. But, for something like a Team Up char, I want to use the in game alternative. Why am I complaining? because the spawns are set on a timer and they only ever spawn once every few minutes (Sorry I do not know the specifics) and you can't farm. That's fine, but I really think they should atleast add extra splinters for reasons like increased difficulty boss fights, X-Defense etc.Another would be some forms of repition, mostly because sometimes the Midtown patrol spawns the same bosses or the same enemies without giving you more challenge. This is minor, because it can be fixed wiht a simple difficulty change from Normal to Heroic (Hard).Overall, I really enjoy this game, and thats suprising because I never always liked Free To PLay games (AHem. APB. I am looking at you.) and I never liked Pay to Win, but this Pay to Win is a good system.

content:
8, 2016
												Wow yeah, where to start.I will give this game a fair review from my perspective.This f2p game is actually quite good since you can get all the things in the game without paying for anything except for stash, with that said you will have to invest alot of hours into it that way.There is alot of Heroes to choose from, some are unique, some heroes got the same skill as another but reskinned and some are just uninteresting.The power effects that the heroes have are in most cases really good, it looks good to destroy the screen with lightning, magic and laser beams.This game is an arpg much like Diablo 2, it got a story mode, it got kill everything you see zones, it got raids and diffrent levels of difficulties.Everything which will feel very repetitive after awhile as you are trying to get the item drops that you want.I can't help to feel that this game is shallow somehow and I have tried to like this game but it just doesn't connect with me.Then we have the store in this game.It is really, really overpriced and I don't see an excuse to why it is that expensive.If you want to unlock all the characters in this game without spending alot of hours, then it will have the same price as 3-4 AAA games at release. This game is good for being a f2p game but it's not that good that it will overshadow 3-4 AAA games worth of price just to have access to the whole game, as in being able to play all of the heroes.Stash will be your biggest problem as a f2p gamer in this game, you will not be able hold alot of items in this game as a f2p gamer.You have several diffrent relics that drops, runes, artifacts, crafter items, gear and what not.Trust me it will fill your singel free stash space quickly and yes stash space costs you real money.So now to a problem I stumbled upon in this game is the very sensitive nature of the chat in this game.If you invest money in this game then stay away from the social/public chat in this game because your opinion or something that you wrote might very well be taken out of context and have you banned, either 7 days ban or permanently.This server is hosted in the USA and their ''freedom of speech'' is heavily moderated.Don't engage in religion, political, racist or sexist discussion or jokes, someone somewhere is going to get butthurt.Someone might report you and you might lose all your invested money into the game if you get permanently banned.That is going to sting since the store prices are really overpriced.I got banned for 7 days for something I wrote that was cut out of its context and thus the text I wrote was seen as hate speech, admittadly I did have poor choice of wording and that together with cutting my sentence out of its context that the rest of the chat was invested in got me banned.I fooled around in chat like I do in several other games but never have I been even warned or banned for that matter in my whole life as a gamer.My best guess is that I have never been playing on server hosted outside of Europe and thus never felt the crazy restraint of speech before like I have done from a server hosted in the USA.As an exampel I did some research about it and found that a guy got 7 days banned from writing in the chat that ''Hulk is gay'', whether or not that is true I can't confirm but I wouldn't be suprised if it was.I am thankful and happy to be living in Europe and God bless all the nations in it and the people.TL;DR:  Test the game you might like it but don't engage in the chat about outwordly things even if the chat is called SOCIAL, some americans are very touchy.I don't recommend this game because for me its a money grabbing game but it's worth a try if you truly go f2p.If you decide to spend money in the game then for the sake of your wallet don't engage with the chat, you might get banned.

content:
er 1, 2014
												This game ranks as one of the best free to play games on Steam as of this writing.A game similar in feel and gameplay to the Diablo and Torchlight games, only you get to play through as your favorite Marvel heroes (and a few villains) - with new characters being introduced regularly. The initial character selection is limited to a few basic heroes, but complete the story mode and you will unlock another random hero for free. Additionally, while you can pay real money to unlock any hero you want (as well as customizing them with various costumes), you can earn every hero in the game for free by collecting Eternity Splinters that drop from time to time.Gameplay is pretty straightforward. Click on an enemy to attack them, with up to six special ability hotkeys (and plenty of skills to choose from). One downside is that many heroes play very similarly at the earlier levels, though you do begin to see some differences as you progress and unlock new abilities, with every hero having a unique ultimate attack that can be unlocked and upgraded.Loot is a big draw here. Like all Diablo-style games, loot will drop regularly and in the familiar rarities (grey garbage, white normal, green uncommon, blue rare, purple epic) as well as a few others (yellow cosmics, red artifacts, gold uniques). Old loot can be sold or 'donated' to a shopkeeper which will, over time, upgrade that shopkeeper so that he or she will offer better items or services.Another benefit of this game is that there are many events that take place which offer chances to get items for free that you might otherwise have to pay for. And speaking of paying for items... this is hardly a 'pay to win' game. Sure, you can pay for an experience boost if you want to level up faster, or you can pay for a potion that will give you a better chance at scoring really good loot, but most pay items are cosmetic. Costumes, pets, and so forth. And while pets can give you small boosts to your stats over time, you can earn free pets that do the same thing.While it isn't exactly breaking any new ground or stepping into new territory, Marvel Heroes is a great game to pass the time either solo or with friends, and if you ever get stuck, the community is generally quite helpful to newer players. I'd recommend this game to anyone, even non-gamers.

												I personally love everything Marvel so I love everything about this game, except the fact that you need to pretty much pay to get multiple heroes past level 10 but it's by no means as bad as other games with microtransactions, especially since this game is free, so the developers need to get their money somewhere. If you like Marvel, get this game, if you are indifferent about Marvel, get it anyway and see what you think of it, if you hate Marvel... yeah, this probably isn't the game for you.
